text: Hillary Clinton and Tim Kaine want to increase the Syrian refugee program by 500...

speaker: Kaine
text: Elaine, I want to...

speaker: Pence
text: Yeah, and so -- but first, you know, let's make sure we're putting the safety and security of the American people first instead of Hillary Clinton expanding the Syrian refugee program...

speaker: Pence
text: The Seventh Circuit...

speaker: Kaine
text: We have different views on -- on refugee issues and on immigration.

speaker: Kaine
text: Hillary and I want to do enforcement based on, are people dangerous?

speaker: Kaine
text: And with respect to refugees, we want to keep people out if they're dangerous.

speaker: Kaine
text: Donald Trump said keep them out if they're Muslim.

speaker: Kaine
text: Mike Pence...

speaker: Pence
text: Absolutely...

speaker: Kaine
text: put a program in place to keep them out if they're from Syria.

speaker: Kaine
text: And yesterday an appellate court with three Republican judges struck down the Pence plan...

speaker: Pence
text: Right.

speaker: Kaine
text: and said it was discriminatory...

speaker: Pence
text: And those judges -- those judges said...

speaker: Pence
text: Elaine, to your point, those judges said it was because there wasn't any evidence yet that -- that ISIS had infiltrated the United States.

speaker: Pence
text: But, look, if you're going to be critical of me on that, that's fair game.

speaker: Kaine
text: But, Governor Pence...

speaker: Kaine
text: But, Governor Pence, I just...

speaker: Pence
text: And I stand by that decision.

speaker: Kaine
text: Sure.

speaker: Kaine
text: Can we just be clear -- Hillary and I will do immigration enforcement and we'll vet refugees based on whether they're dangerous or not.

speaker: Pence
text: But the problem with that...

speaker: Kaine
text: That is completely antithetical to the Jeffersonian values of...

speaker: Pence
text: So -- the FBI...

speaker: Pence
text: The FBI and homeland security said we can't know for certain.

speaker: Pence
text: You've got to err on the side of the safety and security of the American people, Senator.

speaker: Pence
text: I understand the...

speaker: Pence
text: the U.N.

speaker: Pence
text: wants us to expand the Syrian refugee program...

speaker: Quijano
text: Senator Kaine, let me ask you this.

speaker: Quijano
text: Secretary Clinton...

speaker: Quijano
text: What exactly would an intelligence surge look like?

speaker: Kaine
text: Intelligence surge is two-thirds, Elaine.

speaker: Kaine
text: It's two things.

speaker: Kaine
text: It's, first, dramatically expanding our intelligence capacities by hiring great professionals, but also we've got some of the best intel and cyber employees in the world right here in the United States working for many of our private sector companies.

speaker: Kaine
text: So it involves increasing our own workforce, but striking great partnerships with some of our cyber and intel experts in the private sector so that we can, consistent with constitutional principles, gather more intelligence.

speaker: Kaine
text: But the second piece of this is really, really important.

speaker: Kaine
text: It also means creating stronger alliances, because you gather intelligence and then you share your intelligence back and forth with allies.

speaker: Kaine
text: And that's how you find out who may be trying to recruit, who may be trying to come to one country or the next.

speaker: Kaine
text: Alliances are critical.

speaker: Kaine
text: Well, he said NATO is obsolete.

speaker: Kaine
text: And, look, if you put aside -- push aside your alliances, who you're going to share intelligence with?

speaker: Kaine
text: Hillary Clinton is the secretary of state who knows how to build alliances.

speaker: Kaine
text: She built the sanctions regime around the word that stopped the Iranian nuclear weapons program.

speaker: Kaine
text: And that's what an intelligence surge means.

speaker: Quijano
text: All right.

speaker: Quijano
text: I'd like to turn now to the tragedy in Syria.

speaker: Quijano
text: Two hundred fifty thousand...

speaker: Pence
text: First, Donald Trump just spoke about this issue this week.

speaker: Pence
text: We have got to bring together the best resources of this country to understand that cyber warfare is the new warfare of the asymmetrical enemies that we face in this country.

speaker: Pence
text: We have an intelligence, sir (ph).

speaker: Pence
text: But I will also tell you that it's important in this moment to remember that Hillary Clinton had a private server in her home that had classified information on it...

speaker: Pence
text: Her private server was subject to being hacked by foreign...

speaker: Pence
text: We could put cybersecurity first if we just make sure the next secretary of state doesn't have a private server.

speaker: Kaine
text: And all investigation concluded that not one reasonable prosecutor would take any additional step.

speaker: Kaine
text: You don't get to decide the rights and wrongs of this.

speaker: Kaine
text: We have a justice system that does that.

speaker: Kaine
text: And a Republican FBI director did an investigation and concluded that...

speaker: Quijano
text: All right, we are moving on now.

speaker: Quijano
text: Two hundred fifty thousand people...

speaker: Pence
text: If your son or my son handled classified information the way Hillary Clinton did...

speaker: Quijano
text: one hundred thousand of them children -- Governor...

speaker: Quijano
text: Governor...

speaker: Kaine
text: And they concluded that there was no reasonable prosecutor who would take it further.

speaker: Quijano
text: I want to turn now to Syria.

speaker: Quijano
text: Two hundred fifty thousand people, 100,000 of them children, are under siege in Aleppo, Syria.

speaker: Quijano
text: Bunker buster bombs, cluster munitions, and incendiary weapons are being dropped on them by Russian and Syrian militaries.

speaker: Quijano
text: Does the U.S.

speaker: Pence
text: The United States of America needs to begin to exercise strong leadership to protect the vulnerable citizens and over 100,000 children in Aleppo.

speaker: Pence
text: Hillary Clinton's top priority when she became secretary of state was the Russian reset, the Russians reset.

speaker: Pence
text: After the Russian reset, the Russians invaded Ukraine and took over Crimea.

speaker: Pence
text: And the small and bullying leader of Russia is now dictating terms to the United States to the point where all the United States of America -- the greatest nation on Earth -- just withdraws from talks about a cease-fire while Vladimir Putin puts a missile defense system in Syria while he marshals the forces and begins -- look, we have got to begin to lean into this with strong, broad-shouldered American leadership.

speaker: Pence
text: It begins by rebuilding our military.

speaker: Pence
text: And the Russians and the Chinese have been making enormous investments in the military.

speaker: Pence
text: We have the smallest Navy since 1916.

speaker: Pence
text: We have the lowest number of troops since the end of the Second World War.

speaker: Pence
text: We've got to work with Congress, and Donald Trump will, to rebuild our military and project American strength in the world.

speaker: Pence
text: But about Aleppo and about Syria, I truly do believe that what America ought to do right now is immediately establish safe zones, so that families and vulnerable families with children can move out of those areas, work with our Arab partners, real time, right now, to make that happen.

speaker: Pence
text: And secondly, I just have to tell you that the provocations by Russia need to be met with American strength.

speaker: Pence
text: And if Russia chooses to be involved and continue, I should say, to be involved in this barbaric attack on civilians in Aleppo, the United States of America should be prepared to use military force to strike military targets of the Assad regime to prevent them from this humanitarian crisis that is taking place in Aleppo.

speaker: Pence
text: There's a broad range of other things that we ought to do, as well.

speaker: Pence
text: We've just got to have American strength on the world stage.

speaker: Kaine
text: Hillary and I also agree that the establishment of humanitarian zones in northern Syria with the provision of international human aid, consistent with the U.N.

speaker: Kaine
text: Security Council resolution that was passed in February 2014, would be a very, very good idea.

speaker: Kaine
text: And Hillary also has the ability to stand up to Russia in a way that this ticket does not.

speaker: Kaine
text: Donald Trump, again and again, has praised Vladimir Putin.

speaker: Kaine
text: And it's clear that he has business dealings with Russian oligarchs who are very connected to Putin.

speaker: Kaine
text: The Trump campaign management team had to be fired a month or so ago because of those shadowy connections with pro-Putin forces.

speaker: Kaine
text: Governor Pence made the odd claim, he said inarguably Vladimir Putin is a better leader than President Obama.

speaker: Kaine
text: Vladimir Putin has run his economy into the ground.

speaker: Kaine
text: He persecutes LGBT folks and journalists.

speaker: Kaine
text: If you don't know the difference between dictatorship and leadership, then you got to go back to a fifth-grade civics class.

speaker: Kaine
text: I'll tell you what offends me...

speaker: Kaine
text: Governor Pence just said -- Governor Pence just said that Donald Trump will rebuild the military.

speaker: Kaine
text: No, he won't.

speaker: Kaine
text: Donald Trump is avoiding paying taxes.

speaker: Kaine
text: The New York Times story -- and we need to get this -- but the New York Times suggested that he probably didn't pay taxes for about 18 years starting in 1995.

speaker: Kaine
text: Those years included the years of 9/11.

speaker: Kaine
text: So get this.

speaker: Kaine
text: On 9/11, Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump's hometown was attacked by the worst terrorist attack in the history of the United States.

speaker: Kaine
text: Young men and women -- young men and women signed up to serve in the military to fight terrorism.

speaker: Kaine
text: Hillary Clinton went to Washington to get funds to rebuild her city and protect first responders, but Donald Trump was fighting a very different fight.

speaker: Kaine
text: He wouldn't support troops.

speaker: Kaine
text: He wouldn't -- he wouldn't support -- this is important, Elaine.

speaker: Kaine
text: And I said about Aleppo, we do agree the notion is we have to create a humanitarian zone in northern Syria.

speaker: Quijano
text: Governor Pence, you had mentioned no-fly zone.

speaker: Quijano
text: Where would you propose setting up a safe zone specifically?

speaker: Pence
text: Well, first and foremost, Donald Trump supports our troops.

speaker: Pence
text: Donald Trump has paid all the taxes that he's -- do you not take deductions?

speaker: Quijano
text: Gentlemen, this is about Syria.

speaker: Quijano
text: I'd like to...

speaker: Pence
text: Honestly, Senator.

speaker: Kaine
text: It is about our troops.

speaker: Pence
text: I understand why you want to change the subject.

speaker: Pence
text: And let me be very clear on this Russian thing.

speaker: Pence
text: The larger question here...

speaker: Raddatz
text: Ladies and gentlemen the Republican nominee for president, Donald J.

speaker: Cooper
text: Thank you very much for being here.

speaker: Cooper
text: We're going to begin with a question from one of the members in our town hall.

speaker: Cooper
text: Each of you will have two minutes to respond to this question.

speaker: Cooper
text: Secretary Clinton, you won the coin toss, so you'll go first.

speaker: Cooper
text: Our first question comes from Patrice Brock.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Thank you, and good evening.

speaker: QUESTION
text: The last debate could have been rated as MA, mature audiences, per TV parental guidelines.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Knowing that educators assign viewing the presidential debates as students' homework, do you feel you're modeling appropriate and positive behavior for today's youth?

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, thank you.

speaker: Clinton
text: Are you a teacher?

speaker: Clinton
text: Yes, I think that that's a very good question, because I've heard from lots of teachers and parents about some of their concerns about some of the things that are being said and done in this campaign.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I think it is very important for us to make clear to our children that our country really is great because we're good.

speaker: Clinton
text: And we are going to respect one another, lift each other up.

speaker: Clinton
text: We are going to be looking for ways to celebrate our diversity, and we are going to try to reach out to every boy and girl, as well as every adult, to bring them in to working on behalf of our country.

speaker: Clinton
text: I have a very positive and optimistic view about what we can do together.

speaker: Clinton
text: That's why the slogan of my campaign is "Stronger Together," because I think if we work together, if we overcome the divisiveness that sometimes sets Americans against one another, and instead we make some big goals -- and I've set forth some big goals, getting the economy to work for everyone, not just those at the top, making sure that we have the best education system from preschool through college and making it affordable, and so much else.

speaker: Clinton
text: If we set those goals and we go together to try to achieve them, there's nothing in my opinion that America can't do.

speaker: Clinton
text: So that's why I hope that we will come together in this campaign.

speaker: Clinton
text: Obviously, I'm hoping to earn your vote, I'm hoping to be elected in November, and I can promise you, I will work with every American.

speaker: Clinton
text: I want to be the president for all Americans, regardless of your political beliefs, where you come from, what you look like, your religion.

speaker: Clinton
text: I want us to heal our country and bring it together because that's, I think, the best way for us to get the future that our children and our grandchildren deserve.

speaker: Cooper
text: Secretary Clinton, thank you.

speaker: Cooper
text: Mr.

speaker: Cooper
text: Trump, you have two minutes.

speaker: Trump
text: Well, I actually agree with that.

speaker: Trump
text: I agree with everything she said.

speaker: Trump
text: I began this campaign because I was so tired of seeing such foolish things happen to our country.

speaker: Trump
text: This is a great country.

speaker: Trump
text: This is a great land.

speaker: Trump
text: I've gotten to know the people of the country over the last year-and-a-half that I've been doing this as a politician.

speaker: Trump
text: I cannot believe I'm saying that about myself, but I guess I have been a politician.

speaker: Trump
text: And my whole concept was to make America great again.

speaker: Trump
text: When I watch the deals being made, when I watch what's happening with some horrible things like Obamacare, where your health insurance and health care is going up by numbers that are astronomical, 68 percent, 59 percent, 71 percent, when I look at the Iran deal and how bad a deal it is for us, it's a one-sided transaction where we're giving back $150 billion to a terrorist state, really, the number one terror state, we've made them a strong country from really a very weak country just three years ago.

speaker: Trump
text: When I look at all of the things that I see and all of the potential that our country has, we have such tremendous potential, whether it's in business and trade, where we're doing so badly.

speaker: Trump
text: Last year, we had almost $800 billion trade deficit.

speaker: Trump
text: In other words, trading with other countries.

speaker: Trump
text: We had an $800 billion deficit.

speaker: Trump
text: It's hard to believe.

speaker: Trump
text: Inconceivable.

speaker: Trump
text: You say who's making these deals?

speaker: Trump
text: We're going the make great deals.

speaker: Trump
text: We're going to have a strong border.

speaker: Trump
text: We're going to bring back law and order.

speaker: Trump
text: Just today, policemen was shot, two killed.

speaker: Trump
text: And this is happening on a weekly basis.

speaker: Trump
text: We have to bring back respect to law enforcement.

speaker: Trump
text: At the same time, we have to take care of people on all sides.

speaker: Trump
text: We need justice.

speaker: Trump
text: But I want to do things that haven't been done, including fixing and making our inner cities better for the African-American citizens that are so great, and for the Latinos, Hispanics, and I look forward to doing it.

speaker: Trump
text: It's called make America great again.

speaker: Cooper
text: Thank you, Mr.

speaker: Cooper
text: Trump.

speaker: Cooper
text: The question from Patrice was about are you both modeling positive and appropriate behavior for today's youth?

speaker: Cooper
text: We received a lot of questions online, Mr.

speaker: Cooper
text: Trump, about the tape that was released on Friday, as you can imagine.

speaker: Cooper
text: You called what you said locker room banter.

speaker: Cooper
text: You described kissing women without consent, grabbing their genitals.

speaker: Cooper
text: That is sexual assault.

speaker: Cooper
text: You bragged that you have sexually assaulted women.

speaker: Cooper
text: Do you understand that?

speaker: Trump
text: No, I didn't say that at all.

speaker: Trump
text: I don't think you understood what was -- this was locker room talk.

speaker: Trump
text: I'm not proud of it.

speaker: Trump
text: I apologize to my family.

speaker: Trump
text: I apologize to the American people.

speaker: Trump
text: Certainly I'm not proud of it.

speaker: Trump
text: But this is locker room talk.

speaker: Trump
text: You know, when we have a world where you have ISIS chopping off heads, where you have -- and, frankly, drowning people in steel cages, where you have wars and horrible, horrible sights all over, where you have so many bad things happening, this is like medieval times.

speaker: Trump
text: We haven't seen anything like this, the carnage all over the world.

speaker: Trump
text: And they look and they see.

speaker: Trump
text: Can you imagine the people that are, frankly, doing so well against us with ISIS?

speaker: Trump
text: And they look at our country and they see what's going on.

speaker: Trump
text: Yes, I'm very embarrassed by it.

speaker: Trump
text: I hate it.

speaker: Trump
text: But it's locker room talk, and it's one of those things.

speaker: Trump
text: I will knock the hell out of ISIS.

speaker: Trump
text: We're going to defeat ISIS.

speaker: Trump
text: ISIS happened a number of years ago in a vacuum that was left because of bad judgment.

speaker: Trump
text: And I will tell you, I will take care of ISIS.

speaker: Cooper
text: So, Mr.

speaker: Cooper
text: Trump...

speaker: Cooper
text: Just for the record, though, are you saying that what you said on that bus 11 years ago that you did not actually kiss women without consent or grope women without consent?

speaker: Trump
text: I have great respect for women.

speaker: Cooper
text: So, for the record, you're saying you never did that?

speaker: Trump
text: I've said things that, frankly, you hear these things I said.

speaker: Trump
text: And I was embarrassed by it.

speaker: Trump
text: But I have tremendous respect for women.

speaker: Trump
text: And women have respect for me.

speaker: Trump
text: And I will tell you: No, I have not.

speaker: Trump
text: And I will tell you that I'm going to make our country safe.

speaker: Trump
text: We're going to have borders in our country, which we don't have now.

speaker: Trump
text: People are pouring into our country, and they're coming in from the Middle East and other places.

speaker: Trump
text: We're going to make America safe again.

speaker: Trump
text: We're going to make America great again, but we're going to make America safe again.

speaker: Trump
text: And we're going to make America wealthy again, because if you don't do that, it just -- it sounds harsh to say, but we have to build up the wealth of our nation.

speaker: Cooper
text: Thank you, Mr.

speaker: Cooper
text: Trump.

speaker: Trump
text: Right now, other nations are taking our jobs and they're taking our wealth.

speaker: Cooper
text: Thank you, Mr.

speaker: Cooper
text: Trump.

speaker: Cooper
text: Secretary Clinton, do you want to respond?

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, like everyone else, I've spent a lot of time thinking over the last 48 hours about what we heard and saw.

speaker: Clinton
text: You know, with prior Republican nominees for president, I disagreed with them on politics, policies, principles, but I never questioned their fitness to serve.

speaker: Clinton
text: Donald Trump is different.

speaker: Clinton
text: I said starting back in June that he was not fit to be president and commander-in-chief.

speaker: Clinton
text: And many Republicans and independents have said the same thing.

speaker: Clinton
text: What we all saw and heard on Friday was Donald talking about women, what he thinks about women, what he does to women.

speaker: Clinton
text: And he has said that the video doesn't represent who he is.

speaker: Clinton
text: But I think it's clear to anyone who heard it that it represents exactly who he is.

speaker: Clinton
text: Because we've seen this throughout the campaign.

speaker: Clinton
text: We have seen him insult women.

speaker: Clinton
text: We've seen him rate women on their appearance, ranking them from one to ten.

speaker: Clinton
text: We've seen him embarrass women on TV and on Twitter.

speaker: Clinton
text: We saw him after the first debate spend nearly a week denigrating a former Miss Universe in the harshest, most personal terms.

speaker: Clinton
text: So, yes, this is who Donald Trump is.

speaker: Clinton
text: But it's not only women, and it's not only this video that raises questions about his fitness to be our president, because he has also targeted immigrants, African- Americans, Latinos, people with disabilities, POWs, Muslims, and so many others.

speaker: Clinton
text: So this is who Donald Trump is.

speaker: Clinton
text: And the question for us, the question our country must answer is that this is not who we are.

speaker: Clinton
text: That's why -- to go back to your question -- I want to send a message -- we all should -- to every boy and girl and, indeed, to the entire world that America already is great, but we are great because we are good, and we will respect one another, and we will work with one another, and we will celebrate our diversity.

speaker: Clinton
text: These are very important values to me, because this is the America that I know and love.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I can pledge to you tonight that this is the America that I will serve if I'm so fortunate enough to become your president.

speaker: Raddatz
text: And we want to get to some questions from online...

speaker: Trump
text: Am I allowed to respond to that?

speaker: Raddatz
text: Yes, you can respond to that.

speaker: Trump
text: It's just words, folks.

speaker: Trump
text: It's just words.

speaker: Trump
text: Those words, I've been hearing them for many years.

speaker: Trump
text: I heard them when they were running for the Senate in New York, where Hillary was going to bring back jobs to upstate New York and she failed.

speaker: Trump
text: I've heard them where Hillary is constantly talking about the inner cities of our country, which are a disaster education-wise, jobwise, safety-wise, in every way possible.

speaker: Trump
text: I'm going to help the African-Americans.

speaker: Trump
text: I'm going to help the Latinos, Hispanics.

speaker: Trump
text: I am going to help the inner cities.

speaker: Trump
text: She's done a terrible job for the African-Americans.

speaker: Trump
text: She wants their vote, and she does nothing, and then she comes back four years later.

speaker: Trump
text: We saw that firsthand when she was United States senator.

speaker: Trump
text: She campaigned where the primary part of her campaign...

speaker: Raddatz
text: Mr.

speaker: Raddatz
text: Trump, Mr.

speaker: Raddatz
text: Trump -- I want to get to audience questions and online questions.

speaker: Trump
text: So, she's allowed to do that, but I'm not allowed to respond?

speaker: Raddatz
text: This tape is generating intense interest.

speaker: Raddatz
text: In just 48 hours, it's become the single most talked about story of the entire 2016 election on Facebook, with millions and millions of people discussing it on the social network.

speaker: Raddatz
text: As we said a moment ago, we do want to bring in questions from voters around country via social media, and our first stays on this topic.

speaker: Raddatz
text: Jeff from Ohio asks on Facebook, "Trump says the campaign has changed him.

speaker: Raddatz
text: When did that happen?" So, Mr.

speaker: Raddatz
text: Trump, let me add to that.

speaker: Raddatz
text: When you walked off that bus at age 59, were you a different man or did that behavior continue until just recently?

speaker: Raddatz
text: And you have two minutes for this.

speaker: Trump
text: It was locker room talk, as I told you.

speaker: Trump
text: That was locker room talk.

speaker: Trump
text: I'm not proud of it.

speaker: Trump
text: I am a person who has great respect for people, for my family, for the people of this country.

speaker: Trump
text: And certainly, I'm not proud of it.

speaker: Trump
text: But that was something that happened.

speaker: Trump
text: If you look at Bill Clinton, far worse.

speaker: Trump
text: Mine are words, and his was action.

speaker: Trump
text: His was what he's done to women.

speaker: Trump
text: There's never been anybody in the history politics in this nation that's been so abusive to women.

speaker: Trump
text: So you can say any way you want to say it, but Bill Clinton was abusive to women.

speaker: Trump
text: Hillary Clinton attacked those same women and attacked them viciously.

speaker: Trump
text: Four of them here tonight.

speaker: Trump
text: One of the women, who is a wonderful woman, at 12 years old, was raped at 12.

speaker: Trump
text: Her client she represented got him off, and she's seen laughing on two separate occasions, laughing at the girl who was raped.

speaker: Trump
text: Kathy Shelton, that young woman is here with us tonight.

speaker: Trump
text: So don't tell me about words.

speaker: Trump
text: I am absolutely -- I apologize for those words.

speaker: Trump
text: But it is things that people say.

speaker: Trump
text: But what President Clinton did, he was impeached, he lost his license to practice law.

speaker: Trump
text: He had to pay an $850,000 fine to one of the women.

speaker: Trump
text: Paula Jones, who's also here tonight.

speaker: Raddatz
text: Can we please hold the applause?

speaker: Raddatz
text: Secretary Clinton, you have two minutes.

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, first, let me start by saying that so much of what he's just said is not right, but he gets to run his campaign any way he chooses.

speaker: Clinton
text: He gets to decide what he wants to talk about.

speaker: Clinton
text: Instead of answering people's questions, talking about our agenda, laying out the plans that we have that we think can make a better life and a better country, that's his choice.

speaker: Clinton
text: And, look, if this were just about one video, maybe what he's saying tonight would be understandable, but everyone can draw their own conclusions at this point about whether or not the man in the video or the man on the stage respects women.

speaker: Clinton
text: But he never apologizes for anything to anyone.

speaker: Clinton
text: He never apologized to Mr.

speaker: Clinton
text: and Mrs.

speaker: Clinton
text: Khan, the Gold Star family whose son, Captain Khan, died in the line of duty in Iraq.

speaker: Clinton
text: And Donald insulted and attacked them for weeks over their religion.

speaker: Clinton
text: He never apologized to the distinguished federal judge who was born in Indiana, but Donald said he couldn't be trusted to be a judge because his parents were, quote, "Mexican."

speaker: Clinton
text: He never apologized to the reporter that he mimicked and mocked on national television and our children were watching.

speaker: Clinton
text: And he never apologized for the racist lie that President Obama was not born in the United States of America.

speaker: Clinton
text: He owes the president an apology, he owes our country an apology, and he needs to take responsibility for his actions and his words.

speaker: Trump
text: Well, you owe the president an apology, because as you know very well, your campaign, Sidney Blumenthal -- he's another real winner that you have -- and he's the one that got this started, along with your campaign manager, and they were on television just two weeks ago, she was, saying exactly that.

speaker: Trump
text: So you really owe him an apology.

speaker: Trump
text: You're the one that sent the pictures around your campaign, sent the pictures around with President Obama in a certain garb.

speaker: Trump
text: That was long before I was ever involved, so you actually owe an apology.

speaker: Trump
text: Number two, Michelle Obama.

speaker: Trump
text: I've gotten to see the commercials that they did on you.

speaker: Trump
text: And I've gotten to see some of the most vicious commercials I've ever seen of Michelle Obama talking about you, Hillary.

speaker: Trump
text: So, you talk about friend?

speaker: Trump
text: Go back and take a look at those commercials, a race where you lost fair and square, unlike the Bernie Sanders race, where you won, but not fair and square, in my opinion.

speaker: Trump
text: And all you have to do is take a look at WikiLeaks and just see what they say about Bernie Sanders and see what Deborah Wasserman Schultz had in mind, because Bernie Sanders, between super-delegates and Deborah Wasserman Schultz, he never had a chance.

speaker: Trump
text: And I was so surprised to see him sign on with the devil.

speaker: Trump
text: But when you talk about apology, I think the one that you should really be apologizing for and the thing that you should be apologizing for are the 33,000 e-mails that you deleted, and that you acid washed, and then the two boxes of e-mails and other things last week that were taken from an office and are now missing.

speaker: Trump
text: And I'll tell you what.

speaker: Trump
text: I didn't think I'd say this, but I'm going to say it, and I hate to say it.

speaker: Trump
text: But if I win, I am going to instruct my attorney general to get a special prosecutor to look into your situation, because there has never been so many lies, so much deception.

speaker: Trump
text: There has never been anything like it, and we're going to have a special prosecutor.

speaker: Trump
text: When I speak, I go out and speak, the people of this country are furious.

speaker: Trump
text: In my opinion, the people that have been long-term workers at the FBI are furious.

speaker: Trump
text: There has never been anything like this, where e-mails -- and you get a subpoena, you get a subpoena, and after getting the subpoena, you delete 33,000 e-mails, and then you acid wash them or bleach them, as you would say, very expensive process.

speaker: Trump
text: So we're going to get a special prosecutor, and we're going to look into it, because you know what?

speaker: Trump
text: People have been -- their lives have been destroyed for doing one-fifth of what you've done.

speaker: Trump
text: And it's a disgrace.

speaker: Trump
text: And honestly, you ought to be ashamed of yourself.

speaker: Clinton
text: because everything he just said is absolutely false, but I'm not surprised.

speaker: Trump
text: Oh, really?

speaker: Raddatz
text: And really, the audience needs to calm down here.

speaker: Clinton
text: I told people that it would be impossible to be fact-checking Donald all the time.

speaker: Clinton
text: I'd never get to talk about anything I want to do and how we're going to really make lives better for people.

speaker: Clinton
text: So, once again, go to HillaryClinton.com.

speaker: Clinton
text: We have literally Trump -- you can fact check him in real time.

speaker: Clinton
text: Last time at the first debate, we had millions of people fact checking, so I expect we'll have millions more fact checking, because, you know, it is -- it's just awfully good that someone with the temperament of Donald Trump is not in charge of the law in our country.

speaker: Raddatz
text: Secretary Clinton...

speaker: Cooper
text: We want to remind the audience to please not talk out loud.

speaker: Cooper
text: Please do not applaud.

speaker: Raddatz
text: And, Secretary Clinton, I do want to follow up on e- mails.

speaker: Raddatz
text: You've said your handing of your e-mails was a mistake.

speaker: Raddatz
text: You disagreed with FBI Director James Comey, calling your handling of classified information, quote, "extremely careless."

speaker: Raddatz
text: The FBI said that there were 110 classified e-mails that were exchanged, eight of which were top secret, and that it was possible hostile actors did gain access to those e-mails.

speaker: Raddatz
text: You don't call that extremely careless?

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, Martha, first, let me say -- and I've said before, but I'll repeat it, because I want everyone to hear it -- that was a mistake, and I take responsibility for using a personal e-mail account.

speaker: Clinton
text: Obviously, if I were to do it over again, I would not.

speaker: Clinton
text: I'm not making any excuses.

speaker: Clinton
text: It was a mistake.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I am very sorry about that.

speaker: Clinton
text: But I think it's also important to point out where there are some misleading accusations from critics and others.

speaker: Clinton
text: After a year-long investigation, there is no evidence that anyone hacked the server I was using and there is no evidence that anyone can point to at all -- anyone who says otherwise has no basis -- that any classified material ended up in the wrong hands.

speaker: Clinton
text: I take classified materials very seriously and always have.

speaker: Clinton
text: When I was on the Senate Armed Services Committee, I was privy to a lot of classified material.

speaker: Clinton
text: Obviously, as secretary of state, I had some of the most important secrets that we possess, such as going after bin Laden.

speaker: Clinton
text: So I am very committed to taking classified information seriously.

speaker: Clinton
text: And as I said, there is no evidence that any classified information ended up in the wrong hands.

speaker: Raddatz
text: OK, we're going to move on.

speaker: Trump
text: And yet she didn't know the word -- the letter C on a document.

speaker: Trump
text: Right?

speaker: Trump
text: She didn't even know what that word -- what that letter meant.

speaker: Trump
text: You know, it's amazing.

speaker: Trump
text: I'm watching Hillary go over facts.

speaker: Trump
text: And she's going after fact after fact, and she's lying again, because she said she -- you know, what she did with the e-mail was fine.

speaker: Trump
text: You think it was fine to delete 33,000 e-mails?

speaker: Trump
text: I don't think so.

speaker: Trump
text: She said the 33,000 e-mails had to do with her daughter's wedding, number one, and a yoga class.

speaker: Trump
text: Well, maybe we'll give three or three or four or five or something.

speaker: Trump
text: 33,000 e-mails deleted, and now she's saying there wasn't anything wrong.

speaker: Trump
text: And more importantly, that was after getting a subpoena.

speaker: Trump
text: That wasn't before.

speaker: Trump
text: That was after.

speaker: Trump
text: She got it from the United States Congress.

speaker: Trump
text: And I'll be honest, I am so disappointed in congressmen, including Republicans, for allowing this to happen.

speaker: Trump
text: Our Justice Department, where our husband goes on to the back of a airplane for 39 minutes, talks to the attorney general days before a ruling is going to be made on her case.

speaker: Trump
text: But for you to say that there was nothing wrong with you deleting 39,000 e-mails, again, you should be ashamed of yourself.

speaker: Trump
text: What you did -- and this is after getting a subpoena from the United States Congress.

speaker: Trump
text: You did that.

speaker: Trump
text: Wait a minute.

speaker: Cooper
text: Secretary Clinton, you can respond, and then we got to move on.

speaker: Trump
text: If you did that in the private sector, you'd be put in jail, let alone after getting a subpoena from the United States Congress.

speaker: Cooper
text: Secretary Clinton, you can respond.

speaker: Cooper
text: Then we have to move on to an audience question.

speaker: Clinton
text: Look, it's just not true.

speaker: Clinton
text: And so please, go to...

speaker: Trump
text: Oh, you didn't delete them?

speaker: Cooper
text: Allow her to respond, please.

speaker: Clinton
text: It was personal e-mails, not official.

speaker: Trump
text: Yeah.

speaker: Clinton
text: Not -- well, we turned over 35,000, so...

speaker: Trump
text: Oh, yeah.

speaker: Trump
text: What about the other 15,000?

speaker: Cooper
text: Please allow her to respond.

speaker: Clinton
text: Yes, that's true, I didn't.

speaker: Clinton
text: I didn't in the first debate, and I'm going to try not to in this debate, because I'd like to get to the questions that the people have brought here tonight to talk to us about.

speaker: Clinton
text: OK, Donald.

speaker: Clinton
text: I know you're into big diversion tonight, anything to avoid talking about your campaign and the way it's exploding and the way Republicans are leaving you.

speaker: Clinton
text: But let's at least focus...

speaker: Clinton
text: on some of the issues that people care about tonight.

speaker: Cooper
text: We have a question here from Ken Karpowicz.

speaker: Cooper
text: He has a question about health care.

speaker: Trump
text: I'd like to know, Anderson, why aren't you bringing up the e-mails?

speaker: Trump
text: I'd like to know.

speaker: Trump
text: Why aren't you bringing...

speaker: Trump
text: No, it hasn't.

speaker: Trump
text: It hasn't.

speaker: Trump
text: And it hasn't been finished at all.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Thank you.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Affordable Care Act, known as Obamacare, it is not affordable.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Premiums have gone up.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Deductibles have gone up.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Copays have gone up.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Prescriptions have gone up.

speaker: QUESTION
text: And the coverage has gone down.

speaker: QUESTION
text: What will you do to bring the cost down and make coverage better?

speaker: Cooper
text: That first one goes to Secretary Clinton, because you started out the last one to the audience.

speaker: Clinton
text: If he wants to start, he can start.

speaker: Clinton
text: No, go ahead, Donald.

speaker: Trump
text: No, I'm a gentlemen, Hillary.

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, I think Donald was about to say he's going to solve it by repealing it and getting rid of the Affordable Care Act.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I'm going to fix it, because I agree with you.

speaker: Clinton
text: Premiums have gotten too high.

speaker: Clinton
text: Copays, deductibles, prescription drug costs, and I've laid out a series of actions that we can take to try to get those costs down.

speaker: Clinton
text: But here's what I don't want people to forget when we're talking about reining in the costs, which has to be the highest priority of the next president, when the Affordable Care Act passed, it wasn't just that 20 million got insurance who didn't have it before.

speaker: Clinton
text: But that in and of itself was a good thing.

speaker: Clinton
text: I meet these people all the time, and they tell me what a difference having that insurance meant to them and their families.

speaker: Clinton
text: But everybody else, the 170 million of us who get health insurance through our employees got big benefits.

speaker: Clinton
text: Number one, insurance companies can't deny you coverage because of a pre-existing condition.

speaker: Clinton
text: Number two, no lifetime limits, which is a big deal if you have serious health problems.

speaker: Clinton
text: Number three, women can't be charged more than men for our health insurance, which is the way it used to be before the Affordable Care Act.

speaker: Clinton
text: Number four, if you're under 26, and your parents have a policy, you can be on that policy until the age of 26, something that didn't happen before.

speaker: Clinton
text: So I want very much to save what works and is good about the Affordable Care Act.

speaker: Clinton
text: But we've got to get costs down.

speaker: Clinton
text: We've got to provide additional help to small businesses so that they can afford to provide health insurance.

speaker: Clinton
text: But if we repeal it, as Donald has proposed, and start over again, all of those benefits I just mentioned are lost to everybody, not just people who get their health insurance on the exchange.

speaker: Clinton
text: And then we would have to start all over again.

speaker: Clinton
text: Right now, we are at 90 percent health insurance coverage.

speaker: Clinton
text: That's the highest we've ever been in our country.

speaker: Cooper
text: Secretary Clinton, your time is up.

speaker: Clinton
text: So I want us to get to 100 percent, but get costs down and keep quality up.

speaker: Cooper
text: Mr.

speaker: Cooper
text: Trump, you have two minutes.

speaker: Trump
text: It is such a great question and it's maybe the question I get almost more than anything else, outside of defense.

speaker: Trump
text: Obamacare is a disaster.

speaker: Trump
text: You know it.

speaker: Trump
text: We all know it.

speaker: Trump
text: It's going up at numbers that nobody's ever seen worldwide.

speaker: Trump
text: Nobody's ever seen numbers like this for health care.

speaker: Trump
text: It's only getting worse.

speaker: Trump
text: In '17, it implodes by itself.

speaker: Trump
text: Their method of fixing it is to go back and ask Congress for more money, more and more money.

speaker: Trump
text: We have right now almost $20 trillion in debt.

speaker: Trump
text: Obamacare will never work.

speaker: Trump
text: It's very bad, very bad health insurance.

speaker: Trump
text: Far too expensive.

speaker: Trump
text: And not only expensive for the person that has it, unbelievably expensive for our country.

speaker: Trump
text: It's going to be one of the biggest line items very shortly.

speaker: Trump
text: We have to repeal it and replace it with something absolutely much less expensive and something that works, where your plan can actually be tailored.

speaker: Trump
text: We have to get rid of the lines around the state, artificial lines, where we stop insurance companies from coming in and competing, because they want -- and President Obama and whoever was working on it -- they want to leave those lines, because that gives the insurance companies essentially monopolies.

speaker: Trump
text: We want competition.

speaker: Trump
text: You will have the finest health care plan there is.

speaker: Trump
text: She wants to go to a single-payer plan, which would be a disaster, somewhat similar to Canada.

speaker: Trump
text: And if you haven't noticed the Canadians, when they need a big operation, when something happens, they come into the United States in many cases because their system is so slow.

speaker: Trump
text: It's catastrophic in certain ways.

speaker: Trump
text: But she wants to go to single payer, which means the government basically rules everything.

speaker: Trump
text: Hillary Clinton has been after this for years.

speaker: Trump
text: Obamacare was the first step.

speaker: Trump
text: Obamacare is a total disaster.

speaker: Trump
text: And not only are your rates going up by numbers that nobody's ever believed, but your deductibles are going up, so that unless you get hit by a truck, you're never going to be able to use it.

speaker: Cooper
text: Mr.

speaker: Cooper
text: Trump, your time...

speaker: Trump
text: It is a disastrous plan, and it has to be repealed and replaced.

speaker: Cooper
text: Secretary Clinton, let me follow up with you.

speaker: Cooper
text: Your husband called Obamacare, quote, "the craziest thing in the world," saying that small-business owners are getting killed as premiums double, coverage is cut in half.

speaker: Cooper
text: Was he mistaken or was the mistake simply telling the truth?

speaker: Clinton
text: No, I mean, he clarified what he meant.

speaker: Clinton
text: And it's very clear.

speaker: Clinton
text: Look, we are in a situation in our country where if we were to start all over again, we might come up with a different system.

speaker: Clinton
text: But we have an employer-based system.

speaker: Clinton
text: That's where the vast majority of people get their health care.

speaker: Clinton
text: And the Affordable Care Act was meant to try to fill the gap between people who were too poor and couldn't put together any resources to afford health care, namely people on Medicaid.

speaker: Clinton
text: Obviously, Medicare, which is a single-payer system, which takes care of our elderly and does a great job doing it, by the way, and then all of the people who were employed, but people who were working but didn't have the money to afford insurance and didn't have anybody, an employer or anybody else, to help them.

speaker: Clinton
text: That was the slot that the Obamacare approach was to take.

speaker: Clinton
text: And like I say, 20 million people now have health insurance.

speaker: Clinton

text: Mr.

text: I've met with a lot of them, and I've heard how important it is for them to feel that they are wanted and included and part of our country, part of our homeland security, and that's what I want to see.

text: And this is a gift to ISIS and the terrorists, violent jihadist terrorists.

text: So I want a country where citizens like you and your family are just as welcome as anyone else.

text: This is going to be the great Trojan horse of all time.

text: We have enough problems in this country.

text: We know nothing about their values and we know nothing about their love for our country.

text: And indeed, you can look at the propaganda on a lot of the terrorists sites, and what Donald Trump says about Muslims is used to recruit fighters, because they want to create a war between us.

text: As I recall, that was something I said about Abraham Lincoln after having seen the wonderful Steven Spielberg movie called "Lincoln."

text: It was a master class watching President Lincoln get the Congress to approve the 13th Amendment.

text: And I was making the point that it is hard sometimes to get the Congress to do what you want to do and you have to keep working at it.

text: And, yes, President Lincoln was trying to convince some people, he used some arguments, convincing other people, he used other arguments.

text: But, you know, let's talk about what's really going on here, Martha, because our intelligence community just came out and said in the last few days that the Kremlin, meaning Putin and the Russian government, are directing the attacks, the hacking on American accounts to influence our election.

text: And WikiLeaks is part of that, as are other sites where the Russians hack information, we don't even know if it's accurate information, and then they put it out.

text: We have never in the history of our country been in a situation where an adversary, a foreign power, is working so hard to influence the outcome of the election.

text: And believe me, they're not doing it to get me elected.

text: They're doing it to try to influence the election for Donald Trump.

text: Now, maybe because he has praised Putin, maybe because he says he agrees with a lot of what Putin wants to do, maybe because he wants to do business in Moscow, I don't know the reasons.

text: And we should demand that Donald release all of his tax returns so that people can see what are the entanglements and the financial relationships that he has...

text: Mr.

text: Well, I think I should respond, because -- so ridiculous.

text: Look, now she's blaming -- she got caught in a total lie.

text: Her papers went out to all her friends at the banks, Goldman Sachs and everybody else, and she said things -- WikiLeaks that just came out.

text: That's one that I haven't...

text: That's the good thing.

text: That's the big difference between Abraham Lincoln and you.

text: That's a big, big difference.

text: We're talking about some difference.

text: I think it would be great if we got along with Russia because we could fight ISIS together, as an example.

text: But I don't know Putin.

text: And the reason they blame Russia because they think they're trying to tarnish me with Russia.

text: I know nothing about Russia.

text: I know -- I know about Russia, but I know nothing about the inner workings of Russia.

text: I have a very, very great balance sheet, so great that when I did the Old Post Office on Pennsylvania Avenue, the United States government, because of my balance sheet, which they actually know very well, chose me to do the Old Post Office, between the White House and Congress, chose me to do the Old Post Office.

text: One of the primary area things, in fact, perhaps the primary thing was balance sheet.

text: But I have no loans with Russia.

speaker: Trump
text: You could go to the United States government, and they would probably tell you that, because they know my sheet very well in order to get that development I had to have.

text: As soon as I have -- first of all, I pay hundreds of millions of dollars in taxes.

text: Warren Buffett took a massive deduction.

text: Many of the people that are giving her all this money that she can do many more commercials than me gave her -- took massive deductions.

speaker: Trump
text: I pay hundreds of millions of dollars in taxes.

speaker: Trump
text: But -- but as soon as my routine audit is finished, I'll release my returns.

speaker: Trump
text: I'll be very proud to.

speaker: Trump
text: They're actually quite great.

speaker: Raddatz
text: Thank you, Mr.

text: Trump.

text: We want to turn, actually, to the topic of taxes.

text: We have a question from Spencer Maass.

text: My question is, what specific tax provisions will you change to ensure the wealthiest Americans pay their fair share in taxes?

text: Mr.

text: One of the greatest provisions for people like me, to be honest with you, I give up a lot when I run, because I knock out the tax code.

text: But we're bringing the tax rate down from 35 percent to 15 percent.

text: We're cutting taxes for the middle class.

text: And I will tell you, Hillary Clinton is raising your taxes, folks.

text: You can look at me.

text: She's raising your taxes really high.

text: And what that's going to do is a disaster for the country.

text: But she is raising your taxes and I'm lowering your taxes.

text: That in itself is a big difference.

text: We are going to be thriving again.

text: We have no growth in this country.

text: There's no growth.

text: If China has a GDP of 7 percent, it's like a national catastrophe.

text: And I think it's so important -- one of the most important things we can do.

text: But she is raising everybody's taxes massively.

speaker: Cooper
text: Secretary Clinton, you have two minutes.

speaker: Cooper
text: The question was, what specific tax provisions will you change to ensure the wealthiest Americans pay their fair share of taxes?

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, everything you've heard just now from Donald is not true.

speaker: Clinton
text: I'm sorry I have to keep saying this, but he lives in an alternative reality.

text: And it is sort of amusing to hear somebody who hasn't paid federal income taxes in maybe 20 years talking about what he's going to do.

text: But I'll tell you what he's going to do.

text: His plan will give the wealthy and corporations the biggest tax cuts they've ever had, more than the Bush tax cuts by at least a factor of two.

text: Donald always takes care of Donald and people like Donald, and this would be a massive gift.

text: And, indeed, the way that he talks about his tax cuts would end up raising taxes on middle-class families, millions of middle-class families.

speaker: Clinton
text: Now, here's what I want to do.

speaker: Clinton
text: I have said nobody who makes less than $250,000 a year -- and that's the vast majority of Americans as you know -- will have their taxes raised, because I think we've got to go where the money is.

speaker: Clinton
text: And the money is with people who have taken advantage of every single break in the tax code.

speaker: Clinton
text: And, yes, when I was a senator, I did vote to close corporate loopholes.

speaker: Clinton
text: I voted to close, I think, one of the loopholes he took advantage of when he claimed a billion-dollar loss that enabled him to avoid paying taxes.

speaker: Clinton
text: I want to have a tax on people who are making a million dollars.

speaker: Clinton
text: It's called the Buffett rule.

speaker: Clinton
text: Yes, Warren Buffett is the one who's gone out and said somebody like him should not be paying a lower tax rate than his secretary.

speaker: Clinton
text: I want to have a surcharge on incomes above $5 million.

speaker: Clinton
text: We have to make up for lost times, because I want to invest in you.

speaker: Clinton
text: I want to invest in hard-working families.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I think it's been unfortunate, but it's happened, that since the Great Recession, the gains have all gone to the top.

speaker: Clinton
text: And we need to reverse that.

speaker: Clinton
text: People like Donald, who paid zero in taxes, zero for our vets, zero for our military, zero for health and education, that is wrong.

speaker: Cooper
text: Thank you, Secretary.

speaker: Clinton
text: And we're going to make sure that nobody, no corporation, and no individual can get away without paying his fair share to support our country.

speaker: Cooper
text: Thank you.

speaker: Cooper
text: I want to give you -- Mr.

text: Trump, I want to give you the chance to respond.

text: I just wanted to tell our viewers what she's referring to.

text: In the last month, taxes were the number-one issue on Facebook for the first time in the campaign.

text: The New York Times published three pages of your 1995 tax returns.

text: They show you claimed a $916 million loss, which means you could have avoided paying personal federal income taxes for years.

text: You've said you pay state taxes, employee taxes, real estate taxes, property taxes.

text: Did you use that $916 million loss to avoid paying personal federal income taxes for years?

text: Of course I do.

speaker: Trump
text: Of course I do.

text: And so do all of her donors, or most of her donors.

text: I know many of her donors.

text: A lot of my -- excuse me, Anderson -- a lot of my write- off was depreciation and other things that Hillary as a senator allowed.

text: And when she said deplorables, she meant it.

speaker: Trump
text: And when she said irredeemable, they're irredeemable, you didn't mention that, but when she said they're irredeemable, to me that might have been even worse.

speaker: Trump
text: She's got tremendous -- she's got tremendous hatred.

speaker: Trump
text: And this country cannot take another four years of Barack Obama, and that's what you're getting with her.

speaker: Cooper
text: Mr.

speaker: Cooper
text: Trump, let me follow up with you.

speaker: Cooper
text: In 2008, you wrote in one of your books that the most important characteristic of a good leader is discipline.

speaker: Cooper
text: You said, if a leader doesn't have it, quote, "he or she won't be one for very long."

speaker: Cooper
text: In the days after the first debate, you sent out a series of tweets from 3 a.m.

speaker: Cooper
text: to 5 a.m., including one that told people to check out a sex tape.

speaker: Cooper
text: Is that the discipline of a good leader?

speaker: Trump
text: No, there wasn't check out a sex tape.

speaker: Trump
text: It was just take a look at the person that she built up to be this wonderful Girl Scout who was no Girl Scout.

speaker: Trump
text: By the way, just so you understand, when she said 3 o'clock in the morning, take a look at Benghazi.

speaker: Trump
text: She said who is going to answer the call at 3 o'clock in the morning?

speaker: Trump
text: Guess what?

speaker: Trump
text: She didn't answer it, because when Ambassador Stevens...

speaker: Cooper
text: The question is, is that the discipline of a good leader?

speaker: Trump
text: 600 -- wait a minute, Anderson, 600 times.

speaker: Trump
text: Well, she said she was awake at 3 o'clock in the morning, and she also sent a tweet out at 3 o'clock in the morning, but I won't even mention that.

speaker: Trump
text: But she said she'll be awake.

speaker: Trump
text: Who's going -- the famous thing, we're going to answer our call at 3 o'clock in the morning.

speaker: Trump
text: Guess what happened?

speaker: Trump
text: Ambassador Stevens -- Ambassador Stevens sent 600 requests for help.

speaker: Trump
text: And the only one she talked to was Sidney Blumenthal, who's her friend and not a good guy, by the way.

speaker: Trump
text: So, you know, she shouldn't be talking about that.

speaker: Trump
text: Now, tweeting happens to be a modern day form of communication.

speaker: Trump
text: I mean, you can like it or not like it.

speaker: Trump
text: I have, between Facebook and Twitter, I have almost 25 million people.

speaker: Trump
text: It's a very effective way of communication.

speaker: Trump
text: So you can put it down, but it is a very effective form of communication.

speaker: Trump
text: I'm not un-proud of it, to be honest with you.

speaker: Cooper
text: Secretary Clinton, does Mr.

speaker: Cooper
text: Trump have the discipline to be a good leader?

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, it's not only my opinion.

speaker: Clinton
text: It's the opinion of many others, national security experts, Republicans, former Republican members of Congress.

speaker: Clinton
text: But it's in part because those of us who have had the great privilege of seeing this job up close and know how difficult it is, and it's not just because I watched my husband take a $300 billion deficit and turn it into a $200 billion surplus, and 23 million new jobs were created, and incomes went up for everybody.

speaker: Clinton
text: Everybody.

speaker: Clinton
text: African-American incomes went up 33 percent.

speaker: Clinton
text: And it's not just because I worked with George W.

speaker: Clinton
text: Bush after 9/11, and I was very proud that when I told him what the city needed, what we needed to recover, he said you've got it, and he never wavered.

speaker: Clinton
text: He stuck with me.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I have worked and I admire President Obama.

speaker: Clinton
text: He inherited the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression.

speaker: Clinton
text: That was a terrible time for our country.

speaker: Raddatz
text: Secretary Clinton, we have to...

speaker: Raddatz
text: Secretary Clinton, we're moving.

speaker: Clinton
text: And $13 trillion in family wealth was wiped out.

speaker: Clinton
text: We are back on the right track.

speaker: Raddatz
text: Secretary Clinton, we are moving to an audience question.

speaker: Raddatz
text: We're almost out of time.

speaker: Raddatz
text: We have another...

speaker: Raddatz
text: Mr.

speaker: Raddatz
text: Trump, Secretary Clinton, we want to get to the audience.

speaker: Raddatz
text: We have another audience question.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Good evening.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Perhaps the most important aspect of this election is the Supreme Court justice.

speaker: Raddatz
text: We begin with your two minutes, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: Clinton
text: Thank you.

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, you're right.

speaker: Clinton
text: This is one of the most important issues in this election.

speaker: Clinton
text: I want to appoint Supreme Court justices who understand the way the world really works, who have real-life experience, who have not just been in a big law firm and maybe clerked for a judge and then gotten on the bench, but, you know, maybe they tried some more cases, they actually understand what people are up against.

speaker: Clinton
text: Because I think the current court has gone in the wrong direction.

speaker: Clinton
text: And so I would want to see the Supreme Court reverse Citizens United and get dark, unaccountable money out of our politics.

speaker: Clinton
text: Donald doesn't agree with that.

speaker: Clinton
text: I would like the Supreme Court to understand that voting rights are still a big problem in many parts of our country, that we don't always do everything we can to make it possible for people of color and older people and young people to be able to exercise their franchise.

speaker: Clinton
text: I want a Supreme Court that will stick with Roe v.

speaker: Clinton
text: Wade and a woman's right to choose, and I want a Supreme Court that will stick with marriage equality.

speaker: Clinton
text: Now, Donald has put forth the names of some people that he would consider.

speaker: Clinton
text: And among the ones that he has suggested are people who would reverse Roe v.

speaker: Clinton
text: Wade and reverse marriage equality.

speaker: Clinton
text: I think that would be a terrible mistake and would take us backwards.

speaker: Clinton
text: I want a Supreme Court that doesn't always side with corporate interests.

speaker: Clinton
text: I want a Supreme Court that understands because you're wealthy and you can give more money to something doesn't mean you have any more rights or should have any more rights than anybody else.

speaker: Clinton
text: So I have very clear views about what I want to see to kind of change the balance on the Supreme Court.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I regret deeply that the Senate has not done its job and they have not permitted a vote on the person that President Obama, a highly qualified person, they've not given him a vote to be able to be have the full complement of nine Supreme Court justices.

speaker: Clinton
text: I think that was a dereliction of duty.

speaker: Clinton
text: I hope that they will see their way to doing it, but if I am so fortunate enough as to be president, I will immediately move to make sure that we fill that, we have nine justices that get to work on behalf of our people.

speaker: Raddatz
text: Thank you, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: Raddatz
text: Thank you.

speaker: Raddatz
text: You're out of time.

speaker: Raddatz
text: Mr.

speaker: Raddatz
text: Trump?

speaker: Trump
text: Justice Scalia, great judge, died recently.

speaker: Trump
text: And we have a vacancy.

speaker: Trump
text: I am looking to appoint judges very much in the mold of Justice Scalia.

speaker: Trump
text: I'm looking for judges -- and I've actually picked 20 of them so that people would see, highly respected, highly thought of, and actually very beautifully reviewed by just about everybody.

speaker: Trump
text: But people that will respect the Constitution of the United States.

speaker: Trump
text: And I think that this is so important.

speaker: Trump
text: Also, the Second Amendment, which is totally under siege by people like Hillary Clinton.

speaker: Trump
text: They'll respect the Second Amendment and what it stands for, what it represents.

speaker: Trump
text: So important to me.

speaker: Trump
text: Now, Hillary mentioned something about contributions just so you understand.

speaker: Trump
text: So I will have in my race more than $100 million put in -- of my money, meaning I'm not taking all of this big money from all of these different corporations like she's doing.

speaker: Trump
text: What I ask is this.

speaker: Trump
text: So I'm putting in more than -- by the time it's finished, I'll have more than $100 million invested.

speaker: Trump
text: Pretty much self-funding money.

speaker: Trump
text: We're raising money for the Republican Party, and we're doing tremendously on the small donations, $61 average or so.

speaker: Trump
text: I ask Hillary, why doesn't -- she made $250 million by being in office.

speaker: Trump
text: She used the power of her office to make a lot of money.

speaker: Trump
text: Why isn't she funding, not for $100 million, but why don't you put $10 million or $20 million or $25 million or $30 million into your own campaign?

speaker: Trump
text: It's $30 million less for special interests that will tell you exactly what to do and it would really, I think, be a nice sign to the American public.

speaker: Trump
text: Why aren't you putting some money in?

speaker: Trump
text: You have a lot of it.

speaker: Trump
text: You've made a lot of it because of the fact that you've been in office.

speaker: Trump
text: Made a lot of it while you were secretary of state, actually.

speaker: Trump
text: So why aren't you putting money into your own campaign?

speaker: Trump
text: I'm just curious.

speaker: Clinton
text: Well...

speaker: Raddatz
text: Thank you very much.

speaker: Clinton
text: The question was about the Supreme Court.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I just want to quickly say, I respect the Second Amendment.

speaker: Clinton
text: But I believe there should be comprehensive background checks, and we should close the gun show loophole, and close the online loophole.

speaker: Raddatz
text: We have -- we have one more question, Mrs.

speaker: Raddatz
text: Clinton.

speaker: Cooper
text: We have one more question from Ken Bone about energy policy.

speaker: QUESTION
text: What steps will your energy policy take to meet our energy needs, while at the same time remaining environmentally friendly and minimizing job loss for fossil power plant workers?

speaker: Cooper
text: Mr.

speaker: Cooper
text: Trump, two minutes?

speaker: Trump
text: Absolutely.

speaker: Trump
text: I think it's such a great question, because energy is under siege by the Obama administration.

speaker: Trump
text: Under absolutely siege.

speaker: Trump
text: The EPA, Environmental Protection Agency, is killing these energy companies.

speaker: Trump
text: And foreign companies are now coming in buying our -- buying so many of our different plants and then re-jiggering the plant so that they can take care of their oil.

speaker: Trump
text: We are killing -- absolutely killing our energy business in this country.

speaker: Trump
text: Now, I'm all for alternative forms of energy, including wind, including solar, et cetera.

speaker: Trump
text: But we need much more than wind and solar.

speaker: Trump
text: And you look at our miners.

speaker: Trump
text: Hillary Clinton wants to put all the miners out of business.

speaker: Trump
text: There is a thing called clean coal.

speaker: Trump
text: Coal will last for 1,000 years in this country.

speaker: Trump
text: Now we have natural gas and so many other things because of technology.

speaker: Trump
text: We have unbelievable -- we have found over the last seven years, we have found tremendous wealth right under our feet.

speaker: Trump
text: So good.

speaker: Trump
text: Especially when you have $20 trillion in debt.

speaker: Trump
text: I will bring our energy companies back.

speaker: Trump
text: They'll be able to compete.

speaker: Trump
text: They'll make money.

speaker: Trump
text: They'll pay off our national debt.

speaker: Trump
text: They'll pay off our tremendous budget deficits, which are tremendous.

speaker: Trump
text: But we are putting our energy companies out of business.

speaker: Trump
text: We have to bring back our workers.

speaker: Trump
text: You take a look at what's happening to steel and the cost of steel and China dumping vast amounts of steel all over the United States, which essentially is killing our steelworkers and our steel companies.

speaker: Trump
text: We have to guard our energy companies.

speaker: Trump
text: We have to make it possible.

speaker: Trump
text: The EPA is so restrictive that they are putting our energy companies out of business.

speaker: Trump
text: And all you have to do is go to a great place like West Virginia or places like Ohio, which is phenomenal, or places like Pennsylvania and you see what they're doing to the people, miners and others in the energy business.

speaker: Trump
text: It's a disgrace.

speaker: Cooper
text: Your time is up.

speaker: Cooper
text: Secretary Clinton, two minutes.

speaker: Clinton
text: And actually -- well, that was very interesting.

speaker: Clinton
text: First of all, China is illegally dumping steel in the United States and Donald Trump is buying it to build his buildings, putting steelworkers and American steel plants out of business.

speaker: Clinton
text: That's something that I fought against as a senator and that I would have a trade prosecutor to make sure that we don't get taken advantage of by China on steel or anything else.

speaker: Clinton
text: You know, because it sounds like you're in the business or you're aware of people in the business -- you know that we are now for the first time ever energy-independent.

speaker: Clinton
text: We are not dependent upon the Middle East.

speaker: Clinton
text: But the Middle East still controls a lot of the prices.

speaker: Clinton
text: So the price of oil has been way down.

speaker: Clinton
text: And that has had a damaging effect on a lot of the oil companies, right?

speaker: Clinton
text: We are, however, producing a lot of natural gas, which serves as a bridge to more renewable fuels.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I think that's an important transition.

speaker: Clinton
text: We've got to remain energy-independent.

speaker: Clinton
text: It gives us much more power and freedom than to be worried about what goes on in the Middle East.

speaker: Clinton
text: We have enough worries over there without having to worry about that.

speaker: Clinton
text: So I have a comprehensive energy policy, but it really does include fighting climate change, because I think that is a serious problem.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I support moving toward more clean, renewable energy as quickly as we can, because I think we can be the 21st century clean energy superpower and create millions of new jobs and businesses.

speaker: Clinton
text: But I also want to be sure that we don't leave people behind.

speaker: Clinton
text: That's why I'm the only candidate from the very beginning of this campaign who had a plan to help us revitalize coal country, because those coal miners and their fathers and their grandfathers, they dug that coal out.

speaker: Clinton
text: A lot of them lost their lives.

speaker: Clinton
text: They were injured, but they turned the lights on and they powered their factories.

speaker: Clinton
text: I don't want to walk away from them.

speaker: Clinton
text: So we've got to do something for them.

speaker: Cooper
text: Secretary Clinton...

speaker: Clinton
text: But the price of coal is down worldwide.

speaker: Clinton
text: And that's exactly what I have proposed.

speaker: Cooper
text: Time is up.

speaker: Cooper
text: We have time for one more...

speaker: Raddatz
text: We have...

speaker: QUESTION
text: Good evening.

speaker: Raddatz
text: Mr.

speaker: Raddatz
text: Trump, would you like to go first?

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, I certainly will, because I think that's a very fair and important question.

speaker: Clinton
text: Look, I respect his children.

speaker: Clinton
text: His children are incredibly able and devoted, and I think that says a lot about Donald.

speaker: Clinton
text: I don't agree with nearly anything else he says or does, but I do respect that.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I think that is something that as a mother and a grandmother is very important to me.

speaker: Clinton
text: So I believe that this election has become in part so -- so conflict-oriented, so intense because there's a lot at stake.

speaker: Clinton
text: This is not an ordinary time, and this is not an ordinary election.

speaker: Clinton
text: We are going to be choosing a president who will set policy for not just four or eight years, but because of some of the important decisions we have to make here at home and around the world, from the Supreme Court to energy and so much else, and so there is a lot at stake.

speaker: Clinton
text: It's one of the most consequential elections that we've had.

speaker: Clinton
text: And that's why I've tried to put forth specific policies and plans, trying to get it off of the personal and put it on to what it is I want to do as president.

speaker: Clinton
text: And that's why I hope people will check on that for themselves so that they can see that, yes, I've spent 30 years, actually maybe a little more, working to help kids and families.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I want to take all that experience to the White House and do that every single day.

speaker: Raddatz
text: Mr.

speaker: Trump
text: Well, I consider her statement about my children to be a very nice compliment.

speaker: Trump
text: I don't know if it was meant to be a compliment, but it is a great -- I'm very proud of my children.

speaker: Trump
text: And they've done a wonderful job, and they've been wonderful, wonderful kids.

speaker: Trump
text: So I consider that a compliment.

speaker: Trump
text: I will say this about Hillary.

speaker: Trump
text: She doesn't quit.

speaker: Trump
text: She doesn't give up.

speaker: Trump
text: I respect that.

speaker: Trump
text: I tell it like it is.

speaker: Trump
text: She's a fighter.

speaker: Trump
text: I disagree with much of what she's fighting for.

speaker: Trump
text: I do disagree with her judgment in many cases.

speaker: Trump
text: But she does fight hard, and she doesn't quit, and she doesn't give up.

speaker: Trump
text: And I consider that to be a very good trait.

speaker: Cooper
text: We want to thank both the candidates.

speaker: Cooper
text: We want to thank the university here.

speaker: Cooper
text: This concludes the town hall meeting.

speaker: Cooper
text: Our thanks to the candidates, the commission, Washington University, and to everybody who watched.

speaker: Wallace
text: Good evening from the Thomas and Mack Center at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas.

speaker: Wallace
text: I'm Chris Wallace of Fox News, and I welcome you to the third and final of the 2016 presidential debates between Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and Donald J.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump.

speaker: Wallace
text: This debate is sponsored by the Commission on Presidential Debates.

speaker: Wallace
text: The commission has designed the format: Six roughly 15-minute segments with two-minute answers to the first question, then open discussion for the rest of each segment.

speaker: Wallace
text: Both campaigns have agreed to those rules.

speaker: Wallace
text: For the record, I decided the topics and the questions in each topic.

speaker: Wallace
text: None of those questions has been shared with the commission or the two candidates.

speaker: Wallace
text: The audience here in the hall has promised to remain silent.

speaker: Wallace
text: No cheers, boos, or other interruptions so we and you can focus on what the candidates have to say.

speaker: Wallace
text: No noise, except right now, as we welcome the Democratic nominee for president, Secretary Clinton, and the Republican nominee for president, Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Secretary Clinton, Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump, welcome.

speaker: Wallace
text: Let's get right to it.

speaker: Wallace
text: The first topic is the Supreme Court.

speaker: Wallace
text: You both talked briefly about the court in the last debate, but I want to drill down on this, because the next president will almost certainly have at least one appointment and likely or possibly two or three appointments.

speaker: Wallace
text: Which means that you will, in effect, determine the balance of the court for what could be the next quarter century.

speaker: Wallace
text: First of all, where do you want to see the court take the country?

speaker: Wallace
text: And secondly, what's your view on how the Constitution should be interpreted?

speaker: Wallace
text: Do the founders' words mean what they say or is it a living document to be applied flexibly according to changing circumstances?

speaker: Wallace
text: In this segment, Secretary Clinton, you go first.

speaker: Wallace
text: You have two minutes.

speaker: Clinton
text: Thank you very much, Chris.

speaker: Clinton
text: And thanks to UNLV for hosting us.

speaker: Clinton
text: You know, I think when we talk about the Supreme Court, it really raises the central issue in this election, namely, what kind of country are we going to be?

speaker: Clinton
text: What kind of opportunities will we provide for our citizens?

speaker: Clinton
text: What kind of rights will Americans have?

speaker: Clinton
text: And I feel strongly that the Supreme Court needs to stand on the side of the American people, not on the side of the powerful corporations and the wealthy.

speaker: Clinton
text: For me, that means that we need a Supreme Court that will stand up on behalf of women's rights, on behalf of the rights of the LGBT community, that will stand up and say no to Citizens United, a decision that has undermined the election system in our country because of the way it permits dark, unaccountable money to come into our electoral system.

speaker: Clinton
text: I have major disagreements with my opponent about these issues and others that will be before the Supreme Court.

speaker: Clinton
text: But I feel that at this point in our country's history, it is important that we not reverse marriage equality, that we not reverse Roe v.

speaker: Clinton
text: Wade, that we stand up against Citizens United, we stand up for the rights of people in the workplace, that we stand up and basically say: The Supreme Court should represent all of us.

speaker: Clinton
text: That's how I see the court, and the kind of people that I would be looking to nominate to the court would be in the great tradition of standing up to the powerful, standing up on behalf of our rights as Americans.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I look forward to having that opportunity.

speaker: Clinton
text: I would hope that the Senate would do its job and confirm the nominee that President Obama has sent to them.

speaker: Clinton
text: That's the way the Constitution fundamentally should operate.

speaker: Clinton
text: The president nominates, and then the Senate advises and consents, or not, but they go forward with the process.
