speaker: Wallace
text: Secretary Clinton, thank you.

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump, same question.

speaker: Wallace
text: Where do you want to see the court take the country?

speaker: Wallace
text: And how do you believe the Constitution should be interpreted?

speaker: Trump
text: Well, first of all, it's great to be with you, and thank you, everybody.

speaker: Trump
text: The Supreme Court: It's what it's all about.

speaker: Trump
text: Our country is so, so -- it's just so imperative that we have the right justices.

speaker: Trump
text: Something happened recently where Justice Ginsburg made some very, very inappropriate statements toward me and toward a tremendous number of people, many, many millions of people that I represent.

speaker: Trump
text: And she was forced to apologize.

speaker: Trump
text: And apologize she did.

speaker: Trump
text: But these were statements that should never, ever have been made.

speaker: Trump
text: We need a Supreme Court that in my opinion is going to uphold the Second Amendment, and all amendments, but the Second Amendment, which is under absolute siege.

speaker: Trump
text: I believe if my opponent should win this race, which I truly don't think will happen, we will have a Second Amendment which will be a very, very small replica of what it is right now.

speaker: Trump
text: But I feel that it's absolutely important that we uphold, because of the fact that it is under such trauma.

speaker: Trump
text: I feel that the justices that I am going to appoint -- and I've named 20 of them -- the justices that I'm going to appoint will be pro-life.

speaker: Trump
text: They will have a conservative bent.

speaker: Trump
text: They will be protecting the Second Amendment.

speaker: Trump
text: They are great scholars in all cases, and they're people of tremendous respect.

speaker: Trump
text: They will interpret the Constitution the way the founders wanted it interpreted.

speaker: Trump
text: And I believe that's very, very important.

speaker: Trump
text: I don't think we should have justices appointed that decide what they want to hear.

speaker: Trump
text: It's all about the Constitution of -- of -- and so important, the Constitution the way it was meant to be.

speaker: Trump
text: And those are the people that I will appoint.

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump, thank you.

speaker: Wallace
text: We now have about 10 minutes for an open discussion.

speaker: Wallace
text: I want to focus on two issues that, in fact, by the justices that you name could end up changing the existing law of the land.

speaker: Wallace
text: First is one that you mentioned, Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump, and that is guns.

speaker: Wallace
text: Secretary Clinton, you said last year, let me quote, "The Supreme Court is wrong on the Second Amendment."

speaker: Wallace
text: And now, in fact, in the 2008 Heller case, the court ruled that there is a constitutional right to bear arms, but a right that is reasonably limited.

speaker: Wallace
text: Those were the words of the Judge Antonin Scalia who wrote the decision.

speaker: Wallace
text: What's wrong with that?

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, first of all, I support the Second Amendment.

speaker: Clinton
text: I lived in Arkansas for 18 wonderful years.

speaker: Clinton
text: I represented upstate New York.

speaker: Clinton
text: I understand and respect the tradition of gun ownership.

speaker: Clinton
text: It goes back to the founding of our country.

speaker: Clinton
text: But I also believe that there can be and must be reasonable regulation.

speaker: Clinton
text: Because I support the Second Amendment doesn't mean that I want people who shouldn't have guns to be able to threaten you, kill you or members of your family.

speaker: Clinton
text: And so when I think about what we need to do, we have 33,000 people a year who die from guns.

speaker: Clinton
text: I think we need comprehensive background checks, need to close the online loophole, close the gun show loophole.

speaker: Clinton
text: There's other matters that I think are sensible that are the kind of reforms that would make a difference that are not in any way conflicting with the Second Amendment.

speaker: Clinton
text: You mentioned the Heller decision.

speaker: Clinton
text: And what I was saying that you referenced, Chris, was that I disagreed with the way the court applied the Second Amendment in that case, because what the District of Columbia was trying to do was to protect toddlers from guns and so they wanted people with guns to safely store them.

speaker: Clinton
text: And the court didn't accept that reasonable regulation, but they've accepted many others.

speaker: Clinton
text: So I see no conflict between saving people's lives and defending the Second Amendment.

speaker: Wallace
text: Let me bring Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump in here.

speaker: Wallace
text: The bipartisan Open Debate Coalition got millions of votes on questions to ask here, and this was, in fact, one of the top questions that they got.

speaker: Wallace
text: How will you ensure the Second Amendment is protected?

speaker: Wallace
text: You just heard Secretary Clinton's answer.

speaker: Wallace
text: Does she persuade you that, while you may disagree on regulation, that, in fact, she supports a Second Amendment right to bear arms?

speaker: Trump
text: Well, the D.C.

speaker: Trump
text: vs.

speaker: Trump
text: Heller decision was very strongly -- and she was extremely angry about it.

speaker: Trump
text: I watched.

speaker: Trump
text: I mean, she was very, very angry when upheld.

speaker: Trump
text: And Justice Scalia was so involved.

speaker: Trump
text: And it was a well-crafted decision.

speaker: Trump
text: But Hillary was extremely upset, extremely angry.

speaker: Trump
text: And people that believe in the Second Amendment and believe in it very strongly were very upset with what she had to say.

speaker: Wallace
text: Well, let me bring in Secretary Clinton.

speaker: Wallace
text: Were you extremely upset?

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, I was upset because, unfortunately, dozens of toddlers injure themselves, even kill people with guns, because, unfortunately, not everyone who has loaded guns in their homes takes appropriate precautions.

speaker: Clinton
text: But there's no doubt that I respect the Second Amendment, that I also believe there's an individual right to bear arms.

speaker: Clinton
text: That is not in conflict with sensible, commonsense regulation.

speaker: Clinton
text: And, you know, look, I understand that Donald's been strongly supported by the NRA.

speaker: Clinton
text: The gun lobby's on his side.

speaker: Clinton
text: They're running millions of dollars of ads against me.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I regret that, because what I would like to see is for people to come together and say: Of course we're going to protect and defend the Second Amendment.

speaker: Clinton
text: But we're going to do it in a way that tries to save some of these 33,000 lives that we lose every year.

speaker: Wallace
text: Let me bring Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump back into this, because, in fact, you oppose any limits on assault weapons, any limits on high- capacity magazines.

speaker: Wallace
text: You support a national right to carry law.

speaker: Wallace
text: Why, sir?

speaker: Trump
text: Well, let me just tell you before we go any further.

speaker: Trump
text: In Chicago, which has the toughest gun laws in the United States, probably you could say by far, they have more gun violence than any other city.

speaker: Trump
text: So we have the toughest laws, and you have tremendous gun violence.

speaker: Trump
text: I am a very strong supporter of the Second Amendment.

speaker: Trump
text: And I am -- I don't know if Hillary was saying it in a sarcastic manner, but I'm very proud to have the endorsement of the NRA.

speaker: Trump
text: And it's the earliest endorsement they've ever given to anybody who ran for president.

speaker: Trump
text: So I'm very honored by all of that.

speaker: Trump
text: We are going to appoint justices -- this is the best way to help the Second Amendment.

speaker: Trump
text: We are going to appoint justices that will feel very strongly about the Second Amendment, that will not do damage to the Second Amendment.

speaker: Wallace
text: Well, let's pick up on another issue which divides you and the justices that whoever ends up winning this election appoints could have a dramatic effect there, and that's the issue of abortion.

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump, you're pro-life.

speaker: Wallace
text: But I want to ask you specifically: Do you want the court, including the justices that you will name, to overturn Roe v.

speaker: Wallace
text: Wade, which includes -- in fact, states -- a woman's right to abortion?

speaker: Trump
text: Well, if that would happen, because I am pro-life, and I will be appointing pro-life judges, I would think that that will go back to the individual states.

speaker: Wallace
text: But I'm asking you specifically.

speaker: Wallace
text: Would you like to...

speaker: Trump
text: If they overturned it, it will go back to the states.

speaker: Wallace
text: But what I'm asking you, sir, is, do you want to see the court overturn -- you just said you want to see the court protect the Second Amendment.

speaker: Wallace
text: Do you want to see the court overturn Roe v.

speaker: Wallace
text: Wade?

speaker: Trump
text: Well, if we put another two or perhaps three justice on, that's really what's going to be -- that will happen.

speaker: Trump
text: And that'll happen automatically, in my opinion, because I am putting pro-life justices on the court.

speaker: Trump
text: I will say this: It will go back to the states, and the states will then make a determination.

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, I strongly support Roe v.

speaker: Clinton
text: Wade, which guarantees a constitutional right to a woman to make the most intimate, most difficult, in many cases, decisions about her health care that one can imagine.

speaker: Clinton
text: And in this case, it's not only about Roe v.

speaker: Clinton
text: Wade.

speaker: Clinton
text: It is about what's happening right now in America.

speaker: Clinton
text: So many states are putting very stringent regulations on women that block them from exercising that choice to the extent that they are defunding Planned Parenthood, which, of course, provides all kinds of cancer screenings and other benefits for women in our country.

speaker: Clinton
text: Donald has said he's in favor of defunding Planned Parenthood.

speaker: Clinton
text: He even supported shutting the government down to defund Planned Parenthood.

speaker: Clinton
text: I will defend Planned Parenthood.

speaker: Clinton
text: I will defend Roe v.

speaker: Clinton
text: Wade, and I will defend women's rights to make their own health care decisions.

speaker: Wallace
text: Secretary Clinton...

speaker: Clinton
text: And we have come too far to have that turned back now.

speaker: Clinton
text: And, indeed, he said women should be punished, that there should be some form of punishment for women who obtain abortions.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I could just not be more opposed to that kind of thinking.

speaker: Wallace
text: I'm going to give you a chance to respond, but I want to ask you, Secretary Clinton, I want to explore how far you believe the right to abortion goes.

speaker: Wallace
text: You have been quoted as saying that the fetus has no constitutional rights.

speaker: Wallace
text: You also voted against a ban on late-term, partial-birth abortions.

speaker: Wallace
text: Why?

speaker: Clinton
text: Because Roe v.

speaker: Clinton
text: Wade very clearly sets out that there can be regulations on abortion so long as the life and the health of the mother are taken into account.

speaker: Clinton
text: And when I voted as a senator, I did not think that that was the case.

speaker: Clinton
text: The kinds of cases that fall at the end of pregnancy are often the most heartbreaking, painful decisions for families to make.

speaker: Clinton
text: I have met with women who toward the end of their pregnancy get the worst news one could get, that their health is in jeopardy if they continue to carry to term or that something terrible has happened or just been discovered about the pregnancy.

speaker: Clinton
text: I do not think the United States government should be stepping in and making those most personal of decisions.

speaker: Clinton
text: So you can regulate if you are doing so with the life and the health of the mother taken into account.

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump, your reaction?

speaker: Wallace
text: And particularly on this issue of late-term, partial-birth abortions.

speaker: Trump
text: Well, I think it's terrible.

speaker: Trump
text: If you go with what Hillary is saying, in the ninth month, you can take the baby and rip the baby out of the womb of the mother just prior to the birth of the baby.

speaker: Trump
text: Now, you can say that that's OK and Hillary can say that that's OK.

speaker: Trump
text: But it's not OK with me, because based on what she's saying, and based on where she's going, and where she's been, you can take the baby and rip the baby out of the womb in the ninth month on the final day.

speaker: Trump
text: And that's not acceptable.

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, that is not what happens in these cases.

speaker: Clinton
text: And using that kind of scare rhetoric is just terribly unfortunate.

speaker: Clinton
text: You should meet with some of the women that I have met with, women I have known over the course of my life.

speaker: Clinton
text: This is one of the worst possible choices that any woman and her family has to make.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I do not believe the government should be making it.

speaker: Clinton
text: You know, I've had the great honor of traveling across the world on behalf of our country.

speaker: Clinton
text: I've been to countries where governments either forced women to have abortions, like they used to do in China, or forced women to bear children, like they used to do in Romania.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I can tell you: The government has no business in the decisions that women make with their families in accordance with their faith, with medical advice.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I will stand up for that right.

speaker: Wallace
text: All right.

speaker: Wallace
text: But just briefly, I want to move on to another segment...

speaker: Trump
text: And, honestly, nobody has business doing what I just said, doing that, as late as one or two or three or four days prior to birth.

speaker: Trump
text: Nobody has that.

speaker: Wallace
text: All right.

speaker: Wallace
text: Let's move on to the subject of immigration.

speaker: Wallace
text: And there is almost no issue that separates the two of you more than the issue of immigration.

speaker: Wallace
text: Actually, there are a lot of issues that separate the two of you.

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump, you want to build a wall.

speaker: Wallace
text: Secretary Clinton, you have offered no specific plan for how you want to secure our southern border.

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump, you are calling for major deportations.

speaker: Wallace
text: Secretary Clinton, you say that within your first 100 days as president you're going to offer a package that includes a pathway to citizenship.

speaker: Wallace
text: The question, really, is, why are you right and your opponent wrong?

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump, you go first in this segment.

speaker: Wallace
text: You have two minutes.

speaker: Trump
text: Well, first of all, she wants to give amnesty, which is a disaster and very unfair to all of the people that are waiting on line for many, many years.

speaker: Trump
text: We need strong borders.

speaker: Trump
text: In the audience tonight, we have four mothers of -- I mean, these are unbelievable people that I've gotten to know over a period of years whose children have been killed, brutally killed by people that came into the country illegally.

speaker: Trump
text: You have thousands of mothers and fathers and relatives all over the country.

speaker: Trump
text: They're coming in illegally.

speaker: Trump
text: Drugs are pouring in through the border.

speaker: Trump
text: We have no country if we have no border.

speaker: Trump
text: Hillary wants to give amnesty.

speaker: Trump
text: She wants to have open borders.

speaker: Trump
text: The border -- as you know, the Border Patrol agents, 16,500-plus ICE last week, endorsed me.

speaker: Trump
text: First time they've ever endorsed a candidate.

speaker: Trump
text: It means their job is tougher.

speaker: Trump
text: But they know what's going on.

speaker: Trump
text: They know it better than anybody.

speaker: Trump
text: They want strong borders.

speaker: Trump
text: They feel we have to have strong borders.

speaker: Trump
text: I was up in New Hampshire the other day.

speaker: Trump
text: The biggest complaint they have -- it's with all of the problems going on in the world, many of the problems caused by Hillary Clinton and by Barack Obama.

speaker: Trump
text: All of the problems -- the single biggest problem is heroin that pours across our southern border.

speaker: Trump
text: It's just pouring and destroying their youth.

speaker: Trump
text: It's poisoning the blood of their youth and plenty of other people.

speaker: Trump
text: We have to have strong borders.

speaker: Trump
text: We have to keep the drugs out of our country.

speaker: Trump
text: We are -- right now, we're getting the drugs, they're getting the cash.

speaker: Trump
text: We need strong borders.

speaker: Trump
text: We need absolute -- we cannot give amnesty.

speaker: Trump
text: Now, I want to build the wall.

speaker: Trump
text: We need the wall.

speaker: Trump
text: And the Border Patrol, ICE, they all want the wall.

speaker: Trump
text: We stop the drugs.

speaker: Trump
text: We shore up the border.

speaker: Trump
text: One of my first acts will be to get all of the drug lords, all of the bad ones -- we have some bad, bad people in this country that have to go out.

speaker: Trump
text: We're going to get them out; we're going to secure the border.

speaker: Trump
text: And once the border is secured, at a later date, we'll make a determination as to the rest.

speaker: Trump
text: But we have some bad hombres here, and we're going to get them out.

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump, thank you.

speaker: Wallace
text: Same question to you, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: Wallace
text: Basically, why are you right and Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump is wrong?

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, as he was talking, I was thinking about a young girl I met here in Las Vegas, Carla, who is very worried that her parents might be deported, because she was born in this country but they were not.

speaker: Clinton
text: They work hard, they do everything they can to give her a good life.

speaker: Clinton
text: And you're right.

speaker: Clinton
text: I don't want to rip families apart.

speaker: Clinton
text: I don't want to be sending parents away from children.

speaker: Clinton
text: I don't want to see the deportation force that Donald has talked about in action in our country.

speaker: Clinton
text: We have 11 million undocumented people.

speaker: Clinton
text: They have 4 million American citizen children, 15 million people.

speaker: Clinton
text: He said as recently as a few weeks ago in Phoenix that every undocumented person would be subject to deportation.

speaker: Clinton
text: Now, here's what that means.

speaker: Clinton
text: It means you would have to have a massive law enforcement presence, where law enforcement officers would be going school to school, home to home, business to business, rounding up people who are undocumented.

speaker: Clinton
text: And we would then have to put them on trains, on buses to get them out of our country.

speaker: Clinton
text: I think that is an idea that is not in keeping with who we are as a nation.

speaker: Clinton
text: I think it's an idea that would rip our country apart.

speaker: Clinton
text: I have been for border security for years.

speaker: Clinton
text: I voted for border security in the United States Senate.

speaker: Clinton
text: And my comprehensive immigration reform plan of course includes border security.

speaker: Clinton
text: But I want to put our resources where I think they're most needed: Getting rid of any violent person.

speaker: Clinton
text: Anybody who should be deported, we should deport them.

speaker: Clinton
text: When it comes to the wall that Donald talks about building, he went to Mexico, he had a meeting with the Mexican president.

speaker: Clinton
text: Didn't even raise it.

speaker: Clinton
text: He choked and then got into a Twitter war because the Mexican president said we're not paying for that wall.

speaker: Clinton
text: So I think we are both a nation of immigrants and we are a nation of laws and that we can act accordingly.

speaker: Clinton
text: And that's why I'm introducing comprehensive immigration reform within the first 100 days with the path to citizenship.

speaker: Wallace
text: Thank you, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: Wallace
text: I want to follow up...

speaker: Trump
text: Chris, I think it's...

speaker: Trump
text: I think I should respond to that.

speaker: Trump
text: First of all, I had a very good meeting with the president of Mexico.

speaker: Trump
text: Very nice man.

speaker: Trump
text: We will be doing very much better with Mexico on trade deals.

speaker: Trump
text: Believe me.

speaker: Trump
text: The NAFTA deal signed by her husband is one of the worst deals ever made of any kind, signed by anybody.

speaker: Trump
text: It's a disaster.

speaker: Trump
text: Hillary Clinton wanted the wall.

speaker: Trump
text: Hillary Clinton fought for the wall in 2006 or thereabouts.

speaker: Trump
text: Now, she never gets anything done, so naturally the wall wasn't built.

speaker: Trump
text: But Hillary Clinton wanted the wall.

speaker: Wallace
text: Well, let me -- wait, wait, sir, let me...

speaker: Trump
text: We are a country of laws.

speaker: Trump
text: We either have -- and by the way...

speaker: Wallace
text: Now, wait.

speaker: Wallace
text: I'd like to hear from...

speaker: Trump
text: Well -- well, but she said one thing.

speaker: Clinton
text: I voted for border security, and there are...

speaker: Clinton
text: There are some limited places where that was appropriate.

speaker: Clinton
text: There also is necessarily going to be new technology and how best to deploy that.

speaker: Clinton
text: But it is clear, when you look at what Donald has been proposing, he started his campaign bashing immigrants, calling Mexican immigrants rapists and criminals and drug dealers, that he has a very different view about what we should do to deal with immigrants.

speaker: Clinton
text: Now, what I am also arguing is that bringing undocumented immigrants out from the shadows, putting them into the formal economy will be good, because then employers can't exploit them and undercut Americans' wages.

speaker: Clinton
text: And Donald knows a lot about this.

speaker: Clinton
text: He used undocumented labor to build the Trump Tower.

speaker: Clinton
text: He underpaid undocumented workers, and when they complained, he basically said what a lot of employers do: "You complain, I'll get you deported."

speaker: Clinton
text: I want to get everybody out of the shadows, get the economy working, and not let employers like Donald exploit undocumented workers, which hurts them, but also hurts American workers.

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Trump
text: President Obama has moved millions of people out.

speaker: Trump
text: Nobody knows about it, nobody talks about it.

speaker: Trump
text: But under Obama, millions of people have been moved out of this country.

speaker: Trump
text: They've been deported.

speaker: Trump
text: She doesn't want to say that, but that's what's happened, and that's what happened big league.

speaker: Trump
text: As far as moving these people out and moving -- we either have a country or we don't.

speaker: Trump
text: We're a country of laws.

speaker: Trump
text: We either have a border or we don't.

speaker: Trump
text: Now, you can come back in and you can become a citizen.

speaker: Trump
text: But it's very unfair.

speaker: Trump
text: We have millions of people that did it the right way.

speaker: Trump
text: They're on line.

speaker: Trump
text: They're waiting.

speaker: Trump
text: We're going to speed up the process, big league, because it's very inefficient.

speaker: Trump
text: But they're on line and they're waiting to become citizens.

speaker: Trump
text: Very unfair that somebody runs across the border, becomes a citizen, under her plan, you have open borders.

speaker: Trump
text: You would have a disaster on trade, and you will have a disaster with your open borders.

speaker: Wallace
text: I want to...

speaker: Wallace
text: Secretary Clinton, I want to...

speaker: Clinton
text: We will not have open borders.

speaker: Clinton
text: That is...

speaker: Wallace
text: Well, let me -- Secretary...

speaker: Wallace
text: Secretary Clinton...

speaker: Clinton
text: We will have secure borders, but we'll also have reform.

speaker: Clinton
text: And this used to be a bipartisan issue.

speaker: Clinton
text: Ronald Reagan was the last president...

speaker: Wallace
text: Secretary Clinton, excuse me.

speaker: Wallace
text: Secretary Clinton.

speaker: Clinton
text: to sign immigration reform, and George W.

speaker: Clinton
text: Bush supported it, as well.

speaker: Wallace
text: Secretary Clinton, I want to clear up your position on this issue, because in a speech you gave to a Brazilian bank, for which you were paid $225,000, we've learned from the WikiLeaks, that you said this, and I want to quote.

speaker: Wallace
text: "My dream is a hemispheric common market with open trade and open borders."

speaker: Wallace
text: So that's the question...

speaker: Wallace
text: That's the question.

speaker: Wallace
text: Please quiet, everybody.

speaker: Wallace
text: Is that your dream, open borders?

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, if you went on to read the rest of the sentence, I was talking about energy.

speaker: Clinton
text: You know, we trade more energy with our neighbors than we trade with the rest of the world combined.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I do want us to have an electric grid, an energy system that crosses borders.

speaker: Clinton
text: I think that would be a great benefit to us.

speaker: Clinton
text: But you are very clearly quoting from WikiLeaks.

speaker: Clinton
text: And what's really important about WikiLeaks is that the Russian government has engaged in espionage against Americans.

speaker: Clinton
text: They have hacked American websites, American accounts of private people, of institutions.

speaker: Clinton
text: Then they have given that information to WikiLeaks for the purpose of putting it on the Internet.

speaker: Clinton
text: This has come from the highest levels of the Russian government, clearly, from Putin himself, in an effort, as 17 of our intelligence agencies have confirmed, to influence our election.

speaker: Clinton
text: So I actually think the most important question of this evening, Chris, is, finally, will Donald Trump admit and condemn that the Russians are doing this and make it clear that he will not have the help of Putin in in this election, that he rejects Russian espionage against Americans, which he actually encouraged in the past?

speaker: Clinton
text: Those are the questions we need answered.

speaker: Clinton
text: We've never had anything like this happen in any of our elections before.

speaker: Trump
text: That was a great pivot off the fact that she wants open borders, OK?

speaker: Trump
text: How did we get on to Putin?

speaker: Wallace
text: Hold on -- hold on, wait.

speaker: Wallace
text: Hold on, folks.

speaker: Wallace
text: Because we -- this is going to end up getting out of control.

speaker: Wallace
text: Let's try to keep it quiet so -- for the candidates and for the American people.

speaker: Trump
text: So just to finish on the borders...

speaker: Trump
text: She wants open borders.

speaker: Trump
text: People are going to pour into our country.

speaker: Trump
text: People are going to come in from Syria.

speaker: Trump
text: She wants 550 percent more people than Barack Obama, and he has thousands and thousands of people.

speaker: Trump
text: They have no idea where they come from.

speaker: Trump
text: And you see, we are going to stop radical Islamic terrorism in this country.

speaker: Trump
text: She won't even mention the words, and neither will President Obama.

speaker: Trump
text: So I just want to tell you, she wants open borders.

speaker: Trump
text: Now we can talk about Putin.

speaker: Trump
text: I don't know Putin.

speaker: Trump
text: He said nice things about me.

speaker: Trump
text: If we got along well, that would be good.

speaker: Trump
text: If Russia and the United States got along well and went after ISIS, that would be good.

speaker: Trump
text: He has no respect for her.

speaker: Trump
text: He has no respect for our president.

speaker: Trump
text: And I'll tell you what: We're in very serious trouble, because we have a country with tremendous numbers of nuclear warheads -- 1,800, by the way -- where they expanded and we didn't, 1,800 nuclear warheads.

speaker: Trump
text: And she's playing chicken.

speaker: Trump
text: Look, Putin...

speaker: Wallace
text: Wait, but...

speaker: Trump
text: from everything I see, has no respect for this person.

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, that's because he'd rather have a puppet as president of the United States.

speaker: Trump
text: No puppet.

speaker: Clinton
text: And it's pretty clear...

speaker: Clinton
text: It's pretty clear you won't admit...

speaker: Trump
text: No, you're the puppet.

speaker: Clinton
text: that the Russians have engaged in cyberattacks against the United States of America, that you encouraged espionage against our people, that you are willing to spout the Putin line, sign up for his wish list, break up NATO, do whatever he wants to do, and that you continue to get help from him, because he has a very clear favorite in this race.

speaker: Clinton
text: So I think that this is such an unprecedented situation.

speaker: Clinton
text: We've never had a foreign government trying to interfere in our election.

speaker: Clinton
text: We have 17 -- 17 intelligence agencies, civilian and military, who have all concluded that these espionage attacks, these cyberattacks, come from the highest levels of the Kremlin and they are designed to influence our election.

speaker: Clinton
text: I find that deeply disturbing.

speaker: Wallace
text: Secretary Clinton...

speaker: Clinton
text: And I think it's time you take a stand...

speaker: Trump
text: She has no idea whether it's Russia, China, or anybody else.

speaker: Clinton
text: I am quoting 17...

speaker: Trump
text: Hillary, you have no idea.

speaker: Clinton
text: 17 intelligence -- do you doubt 17 military and civilian...

speaker: Trump
text: Yeah, I doubt it.

speaker: Trump
text: I doubt it.

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, he'd rather believe Vladimir Putin than the military and civilian intelligence professionals who are sworn to protect us.

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump...

speaker: Trump
text: Excuse me.

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Trump
text: Yes, that's fine.

speaker: Wallace
text: And I would like to ask you this direct question.

speaker: Wallace
text: The top national security officials of this country do believe that Russia has been behind these hacks.

speaker: Wallace
text: Even if you don't know for sure whether they are, do you condemn any interference by Russia in the American election?

speaker: Trump
text: Of course I condemn.

speaker: Trump
text: Of course I -- I don't know Putin.

speaker: Trump
text: I never met Putin.

speaker: Trump
text: This is not my best friend.

speaker: Trump
text: But if the United States got along with Russia, wouldn't be so bad.

speaker: Trump
text: Let me tell you, Putin has outsmarted her and Obama at every single step of the way.

speaker: Trump
text: Whether it's Syria, you name it.

speaker: Trump
text: Missiles.

speaker: Trump
text: Take a look at the "start up" that they signed.

speaker: Trump
text: The Russians have said, according to many, many reports, I can't believe they allowed us to do this.

speaker: Trump
text: They create warheads, and we can't.

speaker: Trump
text: The Russians can't believe it.

speaker: Trump
text: She has been outsmarted by Putin.

speaker: Trump
text: And all you have to do is look at the Middle East.

speaker: Trump
text: They've taken over.

speaker: Trump
text: We've spent $6 trillion.

speaker: Trump
text: They've taken over the Middle East.

speaker: Trump
text: She has been outsmarted and outplayed worse than anybody I've ever seen in any government whatsoever.

speaker: Wallace
text: We're a long way away from immigration, but I'm going to let you finish this topic.

speaker: Wallace
text: You got about 45 seconds.

speaker: Clinton
text: I -- I find it ironic that he's raising nuclear weapons.

speaker: Clinton
text: This is a person who has been very cavalier, even casual about the use of nuclear weapons.

speaker: Clinton
text: He's...

speaker: Clinton
text: advocated more countries getting them, Japan, Korea, even Saudi Arabia.

speaker: Clinton
text: He said, well, if we have them, why don't we use them, which I think is terrifying.

speaker: Clinton
text: But here's the deal.

speaker: Clinton
text: The bottom line on nuclear weapons is that when the president gives the order, it must be followed.

speaker: Clinton
text: There's about four minutes between the order being given and the people responsible for launching nuclear weapons to do so.

speaker: Clinton
text: And that's why 10 people who have had that awesome responsibility have come out and, in an unprecedented way, said they would not trust Donald Trump with the nuclear codes or to have his finger on the nuclear button.

speaker: Trump
text: I have 200 generals...

speaker: Trump
text: and admirals, 21 endorsing me, 21 congressional Medal of Honor recipients.

speaker: Trump
text: As far as Japan and other countries, we are being ripped off by everybody in the -- we're defending other countries.

speaker: Trump
text: We are spending a fortune doing it.

speaker: Trump
text: They have the bargain of the century.

speaker: Trump
text: All I said is, we have to renegotiate these agreements, because our country cannot afford to defend Saudi Arabia, Japan, Germany, South Korea, and many other places.

speaker: Trump
text: We cannot continue to afford -- she took that as saying nuclear weapons.

speaker: Trump
text: Look, she's been proven to be a liar on so many different ways.

speaker: Trump
text: This is just another lie.

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, I'm just quoting you when you were asked...

speaker: Trump
text: There's no quote.

speaker: Clinton
text: about a potential nuclear -- nuclear competition in Asia, you said, you know, go ahead, enjoy yourselves, folks.

speaker: Clinton
text: That kind...

speaker: Clinton
text: of language -- well...

speaker: Trump
text: And defend yourselves.

speaker: Trump
text: I didn't say nuclear.

speaker: Clinton
text: The United States has kept the peace -- the United States has kept the peace through our alliances.

speaker: Clinton
text: Donald wants to tear up our alliances.

speaker: Clinton
text: I think it makes the world safer and, frankly, it makes the United States safer.

speaker: Clinton
text: I would work with our allies in Asia, in Europe, in the Middle East, and elsewhere.

speaker: Clinton
text: That's the only way we're going to be able to keep the peace.

speaker: Wallace
text: We're going to -- no, we are going to move on to the next topic, which is the economy.

speaker: Wallace
text: And I hope we handle that as well as we did immigration.

speaker: Wallace
text: You also have very different ideas about how to get the economy growing faster.

speaker: Wallace
text: Secretary Clinton, in your plan, government plays a big role.

speaker: Wallace
text: You see more government spending, more entitlements, more tax credits, more tax penalties.

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump, you want to get government out with lower taxes and less regulation.

speaker: Wallace
text: We're going to drill down into this a little bit more.

speaker: Wallace
text: But in this overview, please explain to me why you believe that your plan will create more jobs and growth for this country and your opponent's plan will not.

speaker: Wallace
text: In this round, you go first, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, I think when the middle class thrives, America thrives.

speaker: Clinton
text: And so my plan is based on growing the economy, giving middle-class families many more opportunities.

speaker: Clinton
text: I want us to have the biggest jobs program since World War II, jobs in infrastructure and advanced manufacturing.

speaker: Clinton
text: I think we can compete with high-wage countries, and I believe we should.

speaker: Clinton
text: New jobs and clean energy, not only to fight climate change, which is a serious problem, but to create new opportunities and new businesses.

speaker: Clinton
text: I want us to do more to help small business.

speaker: Clinton
text: That's where two- thirds of the new jobs are going to come from.

speaker: Clinton
text: I want us to raise the national minimum wage, because people who live in poverty should not -- who work full-time should not still be in poverty.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I sure do want to make sure women get equal pay for the work we do.

speaker: Clinton
text: I feel strongly that we have to have an education system that starts with preschool and goes through college.

speaker: Clinton
text: That's why I want more technical education in high schools and in community colleges, real apprenticeships to prepare young people for the jobs of the future.

speaker: Clinton
text: I want to make college debt-free and for families making less than $125,000, you will not get a tuition bill from a public college or university if the plan that I worked on with Bernie Sanders is enacted.

speaker: Clinton
text: And we're going to work hard to make sure that it is, because we are going to go where the money is.

speaker: Clinton
text: Most of the gains in the last years since the Great Recession have gone to the very top.

speaker: Clinton
text: So we are going to have the wealthy pay their fair share.

speaker: Clinton
text: We're going to have corporations make a contribution greater than they are now to our country.

speaker: Clinton
text: That is a plan that has been analyzed by independent experts which said that it could produce 10 million new jobs.

speaker: Clinton
text: By contrast, Donald's plan has been analyzed to conclude it might lose 3.5 million jobs.

speaker: Clinton
text: Why?

speaker: Clinton
text: Because his whole plan is to cut taxes, to give the biggest tax breaks ever to the wealthy and to corporations, adding $20 trillion to our debt, and causing the kind of dislocation that we have seen before, because it truly will be trickle-down economics on steroids.

speaker: Clinton
text: So the plan I have I think will actually produce greater opportunities.

speaker: Clinton
text: The plan he has will cost us jobs and possibly lead to another Great Recession.

speaker: Wallace
text: Secretary, thank you.

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump, why will your plan create more jobs and growth than Secretary Clinton's?

speaker: Trump
text: Well, first of all, before I start on my plan, her plan is going to raise taxes and even double your taxes.

speaker: Trump
text: Her tax plan is a disaster.

speaker: Trump
text: And she can say all she wants about college tuition.

speaker: Trump
text: And I'm a big proponent.

speaker: Trump
text: We're going to do a lot of things for college tuition.

speaker: Trump
text: But the rest of the public's going to be paying for it.

speaker: Trump
text: We will have a massive, massive tax increase under Hillary Clinton's plan.

speaker: Trump
text: But I'd like to start off where we left, because when I said Japan and Germany, and I'm -- not to single them out, but South Korea, these are very rich, powerful countries.

speaker: Trump
text: Saudi Arabia, nothing but money.

speaker: Trump
text: We protect Saudi Arabia.

speaker: Trump
text: Why aren't they paying?

speaker: Trump
text: She immediately -- when she heard this, I questioned it, and I questioned NATO.

speaker: Trump
text: Why aren't the NATO questioned -- why aren't they paying?

speaker: Trump
text: Because they weren't paying.

speaker: Trump
text: Since I did this -- this was a year ago -- all of a sudden, they're paying.

speaker: Trump
text: And I've been given a lot -- a lot of credit for it.

speaker: Trump
text: All of a sudden, they're starting to pay up.

speaker: Trump
text: They have to pay up.

speaker: Trump
text: We're protecting people, they have to pay up.

speaker: Trump
text: And I'm a big fan of NATO.

speaker: Trump
text: But they have to pay up.

speaker: Trump
text: She comes out and said, we love our allies, we think our allies are great.

speaker: Trump
text: Well, it's awfully hard to get them to pay up when you have somebody saying we think how great they are.

speaker: Trump
text: We have to tell Japan in a very nice way, we have to tell Germany, all of these countries, South Korea, we have to say, you have to help us out.

speaker: Trump
text: We have, during his regime, during President Obama's regime, we've doubled our national debt.

speaker: Trump
text: We're up to $20 trillion.

speaker: Trump
text: So my plan -- we're going to renegotiate trade deals.

speaker: Trump
text: We're going to have a lot of free trade.

speaker: Trump
text: We're going to have free trade, more free trade than we have right now.

speaker: Trump
text: But we have horrible deals.

speaker: Trump
text: Our jobs are being taken out by the deal that her husband signed, NAFTA, one of the worst deals ever.

speaker: Trump
text: Our jobs are being sucked out of our economy.

speaker: Trump
text: You look at all of the places that I just left, you go to Pennsylvania, you go to Ohio, you go to Florida, you go to any of them.

speaker: Trump
text: You go upstate New York.

speaker: Trump
text: Our jobs have fled to Mexico and other places.

speaker: Trump
text: We're bringing our jobs back.

speaker: Trump
text: I am going to renegotiate NAFTA.

speaker: Trump
text: And if I can't make a great deal -- then we're going to terminate NAFTA and we're going to create new deals.

speaker: Trump
text: We're going to have trade, but we're going -- we're going to terminate it, we're going to make a great trade deal.

speaker: Trump
text: And if we can't, we're going to do it -- we're going to go a separate way, because it has been a disaster.

speaker: Trump
text: We are going to cut taxes massively.

speaker: Trump
text: We're going to cut business taxes massively.

speaker: Trump
text: They're going to start hiring people.

speaker: Trump
text: We're going to bring the $2.5 trillion...

speaker: Wallace
text: Time, Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump.

speaker: Trump
text: that's offshore back into the country.

speaker: Trump
text: We are going to start the engine rolling again, because...

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Trump
text: right now, our country is dying at 1 percent GDP.

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, let me translate that, if I can, Chris, because...

speaker: Clinton
text: the fact is, he's going to advocate for the largest tax cuts we've ever seen, three times more than the tax cuts under the Bush administration.

speaker: Clinton
text: I have said repeatedly throughout this campaign: I will not raise taxes on anyone making $250,000 or less.

speaker: Clinton
text: I also will not add a penny to the debt.

speaker: Clinton
text: I have costed out what I'm going to do.

speaker: Clinton
text: He will, through his massive tax cuts, add $20 trillion to the debt.

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, he mentioned the debt.

speaker: Clinton
text: We know how to get control of the debt.

speaker: Clinton
text: When my husband was president, we went from a $300 billion deficit to a $200 billion surplus and we were actually on the path to eliminating the national debt.

speaker: Clinton
text: When President Obama came into office, he inherited the worst economic disaster since the Great Depression.

speaker: Clinton
text: He has cut the deficit by two-thirds.

speaker: Clinton
text: So, yes, one of the ways you go after the debt, one of the ways you create jobs is by investing in people.

speaker: Clinton
text: So I do have investments, investments in new jobs, investments in education, skill training, and the opportunities for people to get ahead and stay ahead.

speaker: Clinton
text: That's the kind of approach that will work.

speaker: Wallace
text: Secretary...

speaker: Clinton
text: Cutting taxes on the wealthy, we've tried that.

speaker: Clinton
text: It has not worked the way that it has been promised.

speaker: Wallace
text: Secretary Clinton, I want to pursue your plan, because in many ways it is similar to the Obama stimulus plan in 2009, which has led to the slowest GDP growth since 1949.

speaker: Wallace
text: Thank you, sir.

speaker: Wallace
text: You told me in July when we spoke that the problem is that President Obama didn't get to do enough in what he was trying to do with his stimulus.

speaker: Wallace
text: So is your plan basically more -- even more of the Obama stimulus?

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, it's a combination, Chris.

speaker: Clinton
text: And let me say that when you inherit the level of economic catastrophe that President Obama inherited, it was a real touch-and-go situation.

speaker: Clinton
text: I was in the Senate before I became secretary of state.

speaker: Clinton
text: I've never seen people as physically distraught as the Bush administration team was because of what was happening to the economy.

speaker: Clinton
text: I personally believe that the steps that President Obama took saved the economy.

speaker: Clinton
text: He doesn't get the credit he deserves for taking some very hard positions.

speaker: Clinton
text: But it was a terrible recession.

speaker: Clinton
text: So now we've dug ourselves out of it, we're standing, but we're not yet running.

speaker: Clinton
text: So what I am proposing is that we invest from the middle out and the ground up, not the top down.

speaker: Clinton
text: That is not going to work.

speaker: Clinton
text: That's why what I have put forward doesn't add a penny to the debt, but it is the kind of approach that will enable more people to take those new jobs, higher-paying jobs.

speaker: Clinton
text: We're beginning to see some increase in incomes, and we certainly have had a long string of increasing jobs.

speaker: Clinton
text: We've got to do more to get the whole economy moving, and that's what I believe I will be able to do.

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump, even conservative economists who have looked at your plan say that the numbers don't add up, that your idea, and you've talked about 25 million jobs created, 4 percent...

speaker: Wallace
text: growth is unrealistic.

speaker: Wallace
text: And they say -- you talk a lot about growing the energy industry.

speaker: Wallace
text: They say with oil prices as low as they are right now, that's unrealistic, as well.

speaker: Wallace
text: Your response, sir?

speaker: Trump
text: So I just left some high representatives of India.

speaker: Trump
text: They're growing at 8 percent.

speaker: Trump
text: China is growing at 7 percent.

speaker: Trump
text: And that for them is a catastrophically low number.

speaker: Trump
text: We are growing -- our last report came out -- and it's right around the 1 percent level.

speaker: Trump
text: And I think it's going down.

speaker: Trump
text: Last week, as you know, the end of last week, they came out with an anemic jobs report.

speaker: Trump
text: A terrible jobs report.

speaker: Trump
text: In fact I said, is that the last jobs report before the election?

speaker: Trump
text: Because if it is, I should win easily, it was so bad.

speaker: Trump
text: The report was so bad.

speaker: Trump
text: Look, our country is stagnant.

speaker: Trump
text: We've lost our jobs.

speaker: Trump
text: We've lost our businesses.

speaker: Trump
text: We're not making things anymore, relatively speaking.

speaker: Trump
text: Our product is pouring in from China, pouring in from Vietnam, pouring in from all over the world.

speaker: Trump
text: I've visited so many communities.

speaker: Trump
text: This has been such an incredible education for me, Chris.

speaker: Trump
text: I've gotten to know so many -- I've developed so many friends over the last year.

speaker: Trump
text: And they cry when they see what's happened.

speaker: Trump
text: I pass factories that were thriving 20, 25 years ago, and because of the bill that her husband signed and she blessed 100 percent, it is just horrible what's happened to these people in these communities.

speaker: Trump
text: Now, she can say that her husband did well, but, boy, did they suffer as NAFTA kicked in, because it didn't really kick in very much, but it kicked in after they left.

speaker: Trump
text: Boy, did they suffer.

speaker: Trump
text: That was one of the worst things that's ever been signed by our country.

speaker: Trump
text: Now she wants to sign Trans-Pacific Partnership.

speaker: Trump
text: And she wants it.

speaker: Trump
text: She lied when she said she didn't call it the gold standard in one of the debates.

speaker: Trump
text: She totally lied.

speaker: Trump
text: She did call it the gold standard.

speaker: Trump
text: And they actually fact checked, and they said I was right.

speaker: Trump
text: I was so honored.

speaker: Wallace
text: I want you to give you a chance to briefly speak to that, and then I want to pivot to one-sixth of the economy...

speaker: Wallace
text: which is Obamacare.

speaker: Wallace
text: But go ahead, briefly.

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, first, let me say, number one, when I saw the final agreement for TPP, I said I was against it.

speaker: Clinton
text: It didn't meet my test.

speaker: Clinton
text: I've had the same test.

speaker: Clinton
text: Does it create jobs, raise incomes, and further our national security?

speaker: Clinton
text: I'm against it now.

speaker: Clinton
text: I'll be against it after the election.

speaker: Clinton
text: I'll be against it when I'm president.

speaker: Clinton
text: There's only one of us on this stage who's actually shipped jobs to Mexico, because that's Donald.

speaker: Clinton
text: He's shipped jobs to 12 countries, including Mexico.

speaker: Clinton
text: But he mentioned China.

speaker: Clinton
text: And, you know, one of the biggest problems we have with China is the illegal dumping of steel and aluminum into our markets.

speaker: Clinton
text: I have fought against that as a senator.

speaker: Clinton
text: I've stood up against it as secretary of state.

speaker: Clinton
text: Donald has bought Chinese steel and aluminum.

speaker: Clinton
text: In fact, the Trump Hotel right here in Las Vegas was made with Chinese steel.

speaker: Clinton
text: So he goes around with crocodile tears about how terrible it is, but he has given jobs to Chinese steelworkers, not American steelworkers.

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Trump
text: Well, let me just say -- let me just say.

speaker: Clinton
text: We're going to pull the country together.

speaker: Clinton
text: We're going to have trade agreements that we enforce.

speaker: Clinton
text: That's why I'm going to have a trade prosecutor for the first time in history.

speaker: Clinton
text: And we're going to enforce those agreements, and we're going to look for businesses to help us by buying American products.

speaker: Wallace
text: Secretary Clinton?

speaker: Wallace
text: Go ahead, Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump.

speaker: Trump
text: Let me ask a simple question.

speaker: Trump
text: She's been doing this for 30 years.

speaker: Trump
text: Why the hell didn't you do it over the last 15, 20 years?

speaker: Clinton
text: No, I voted.

speaker: Trump
text: You were very much involved -- excuse me.

speaker: Trump
text: My turn.

speaker: Trump
text: You were very much involved in every aspect of this country.

speaker: Trump
text: Very much.

speaker: Trump
text: And you do have experience.

speaker: Trump
text: I say the one thing you have over me is experience, but it's bad experience, because what you've done has turned out badly.

speaker: Trump
text: For 30 years, you've been in a position to help, and if you say that I use steel or I use something else, I -- make it impossible for me to do that.

speaker: Trump
text: I wouldn't mind.

speaker: Trump
text: The problem is, you talk, but you don't get anything done, Hillary.

speaker: Trump
text: You don't.

speaker: Trump
text: Just like when you ran the State Department, $6 billion was missing.

speaker: Trump
text: How do you miss $6 billion?

speaker: Trump
text: You ran the State Department, $6 billion was either stolen.

speaker: Trump
text: They don't know.

speaker: Trump
text: It's gone, $6 billion.

speaker: Trump
text: If you become president, this country is going to be in some mess.

speaker: Trump
text: Believe me.

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, first of all, what he just said about the State Department is not only untrue, it's been debunked numerous times.

speaker: Clinton
text: But I think it's really an important issue.

speaker: Clinton
text: He raised the 30 years of experience, so let me just talk briefly about that.

speaker: Clinton
text: You know, back in the 1970s, I worked for the Children's Defense Fund.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I was taking on discrimination against African-American kids in schools.

speaker: Clinton
text: He was getting sued by the Justice Department for racial discrimination in his apartment buildings.

speaker: Clinton
text: In the 1980s, I was working to reform the schools in Arkansas.

speaker: Clinton
text: He was borrowing $14 million from his father to start his businesses.

speaker: Clinton
text: In the 1990s, I went to Beijing and I said women's rights are human rights.

speaker: Clinton
text: He insulted a former Miss Universe, Alicia Machado, called her an eating machine.

speaker: Clinton
text: And on the day when I was in the Situation Room, monitoring the raid that brought Osama bin Laden to justice, he was hosting the "Celebrity Apprentice."

speaker: Clinton
text: So I'm happy to compare my 30 years of experience, what I've done for this country, trying to help in every way I could, especially kids and families get ahead and stay ahead, with your 30 years, and I'll let the American people make that decision.

speaker: Trump
text: Well, I think I did a much better job.

speaker: Trump
text: I built a massive company, a great company, some of the greatest assets anywhere in the world, worth many, many billions of dollars.

speaker: Trump
text: I started with a $1 million loan.

speaker: Trump
text: I agree with that.

speaker: Trump
text: It's a $1 million loan.

speaker: Trump
text: But I built a phenomenal company.

speaker: Trump
text: And if we could run our country the way I've run my company, we would have a country that you would be so proud of.

speaker: Trump
text: You would even be proud of it.

speaker: Trump
text: And frankly, when you look at her real record, take a look at Syria.

speaker: Trump
text: Take a look at the migration.

speaker: Trump
text: Take a look at Libya.

speaker: Trump
text: Take a look at Iraq.

speaker: Trump
text: She gave us ISIS, because her and Obama created this huge vacuum, and a small group came out of that huge vacuum because when -- we should never have been in Iraq, but once we were there, we should have never got out the way they wanted to get out.

speaker: Trump
text: She gave us ISIS as sure as you are sitting there.

speaker: Trump
text: And what happened is now ISIS is in 32 countries.

speaker: Trump
text: And now I listen how she's going to get rid of ISIS.

speaker: Trump
text: She's going to get rid of nobody.

speaker: Wallace
text: All right.

speaker: Wallace
text: We are going to get to foreign hot spots in a few moments, but the next segment is fitness to be president of the United States.

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump, at the last debate, you said your talk about grabbing women was just that, talk, and that you'd never actually done it.

speaker: Wallace
text: And since then, as we all know, nine women have come forward and have said that you either groped them or kissed them without their consent.

speaker: Wallace
text: Why would so many different women from so many different circumstances over so many different years, why would they all in this last couple of weeks make up -- you deny this -- why would they all make up these stories?

speaker: Wallace
text: Since this is a question for both of you, Secretary Clinton, Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump says what your husband did and that you defended was even worse.

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump, you go first.

speaker: Trump
text: Well, first of all, those stories have been largely debunked.

speaker: Trump
text: Those people -- I don't know those people.

speaker: Trump
text: I have a feeling how they came.

speaker: Trump
text: I believe it was her campaign that did it.

speaker: Trump
text: Just like if you look at what came out today on the clips where I was wondering what happened with my rally in Chicago and other rallies where we had such violence?

speaker: Trump
text: She's the one and Obama that caused the violence.

speaker: Trump
text: They hired people -- they paid them $1,500, and they're on tape saying be violent, cause fights, do bad things.

speaker: Trump
text: I would say the only way -- because those stories are all totally false, I have to say that.

speaker: Trump
text: And I didn't even apologize to my wife, who's sitting right here, because I didn't do anything.

speaker: Trump
text: I didn't know any of these -- I didn't see these women.

speaker: Trump
text: These women -- the woman on the plane, the -- I think they want either fame or her campaign did it.

speaker: Trump
text: And I think it's her campaign.

speaker: Trump
text: Because what I saw what they did, which is a criminal act, by the way, where they're telling people to go out and start fist-fights and start violence.

speaker: Trump
text: And I'll tell you what, in particular in Chicago, people were hurt and people could have been killed in that riot.

speaker: Trump
text: And that was now all on tape, started by her.

speaker: Trump
text: I believe, Chris, that she got these people to step forward.

speaker: Trump
text: If it wasn't, they get their 10 minutes of fame.

speaker: Trump
text: But they were all totally -- it was all fiction.

speaker: Trump
text: It was lies, and it was fiction.

speaker: Clinton
text: Well...

speaker: Clinton
text: At the last debate, we heard Donald talking about what he did to women.

speaker: Clinton
text: And after that, a number of women have come forward saying that's exactly what he did to them.

speaker: Clinton
text: Now, what was his response?

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, he held a number of big rallies where he said that he could not possibly have done those things to those women because they were not attractive enough for them to be assaulted.

speaker: Trump
text: I did not say that.

speaker: Clinton
text: In fact, he went on to say...

speaker: Wallace
text: Her two minutes -- sir, her two minutes.

speaker: Wallace
text: Her two minutes.

speaker: Clinton
text: He went on to say, "Look at her.

speaker: Clinton
text: I don't think so."

speaker: Clinton
text: About another woman, he said, "That wouldn't be my first choice."

speaker: Clinton
text: He attacked the woman reporter writing the story, called her "disgusting," as he has called a number of women during this campaign.

speaker: Clinton
text: Donald thinks belittling women makes him bigger.

speaker: Clinton
text: He goes after their dignity, their self-worth, and I don't think there is a woman anywhere who doesn't know what that feels like.

speaker: Clinton
text: So we now know what Donald thinks and what he says and how he acts toward women.

speaker: Clinton
text: That's who Donald is.

speaker: Clinton
text: I think it's really up to all of us to demonstrate who we are and who our country is, and to stand up and be very clear about what we expect from our next president, how we want to bring our country together, where we don't want to have the kind of pitting of people one against the other, where instead we celebrate our diversity, we lift people up, and we make our country even greater.

speaker: Clinton
text: America is great, because America is good.

speaker: Clinton
text: And it really is up to all of us to make that true, now and in the future, and particularly for our children and our grandchildren.

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump...

speaker: Trump
text: Nobody has more respect for women than I do.

speaker: Trump
text: Nobody has more respect...

speaker: Wallace
text: Please, everybody.

speaker: Trump
text: And frankly, those stories have been largely debunked.

speaker: Trump
text: And I really want to just talk about something slightly different.

speaker: Trump
text: She mentions this, which is all fiction, all fictionalized, probably or possibly started by her and her very sleazy campaign.

speaker: Trump
text: But I will tell you what isn't fictionalized are her e-mails, where she destroyed 33,000 e-mails criminally, criminally, after getting a subpoena from the United States Congress.

speaker: Trump
text: What happened to the FBI, I don't know.

speaker: Trump
text: We have a great general, four-star general, today you read it in all of the papers, going to potentially serve five years in jail for lying to the FBI.

speaker: Trump
text: One lie.

speaker: Trump
text: She's lied hundreds of times to the people, to Congress, and to the FBI.

speaker: Trump
text: He's going to probably go to jail.

speaker: Trump
text: This is a four-star general.

speaker: Trump
text: And she gets away with it, and she can run for the presidency of the United States?

speaker: Trump
text: That's really what you should be talking about, not fiction, where somebody wants fame or where they come out of her crooked campaign.

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, every time Donald is pushed on something which is obviously uncomfortable, like what these women are saying, he immediately goes to denying responsibility.

speaker: Clinton
text: And it's not just about women.

speaker: Clinton
text: He never apologizes or says he's sorry for anything.

speaker: Clinton
text: So we know what he has said and what he's done to women.

speaker: Clinton
text: But he also went after a disabled reporter, mocked and mimicked him on national television.

speaker: Clinton
text: He went after Mr.

speaker: Clinton
text: and Mrs.

speaker: Clinton
text: Khan, the parents of a young man who died serving our country, a Gold Star family, because of their religion.

speaker: Clinton
text: He went after John McCain, a prisoner of war, said he prefers "people who aren't captured."

speaker: Clinton
text: He went after a federal judge, born in Indiana, but who Donald said couldn't be trusted to try the fraud and racketeering case against Trump University because his parents were Mexican.

speaker: Clinton
text: So it's not one thing.

speaker: Clinton
text: This is a pattern, a pattern of divisiveness, of a very dark and in many ways dangerous vision of our country, where he incites violence, where he applauds people who are pushing and pulling and punching at his rallies.

speaker: Clinton
text: That is not who America is.

speaker: Clinton
