text: We don't know who the rebels are.

speaker: Trump
text: And when and if -- and it's not going to happen, because you have Russia and you have Iran now.

speaker: Trump
text: But if they ever did overthrow Assad, you might end up with -- as bad as Assad is, and he's a bad guy, but you may very well end up with worse than Assad.

speaker: Trump
text: If she did nothing, we'd be in much better shape.

speaker: Trump
text: And this is what's caused the great migration, where she's taking in tens of thousands of Syrian refugees, who probably in many cases -- not probably, who are definitely...

speaker: Wallace
text: Let me...

speaker: Trump
text: in many cases, ISIS-aligned, and we now have them in our country, and wait until you see -- this is going to be the great Trojan horse.

speaker: Trump
text: And wait until you see what happens in the coming years.

speaker: Trump
text: Lots of luck, Hillary.

speaker: Trump
text: Thanks a lot for doing a great job.

speaker: Wallace
text: Secretary Clinton, you have talked about -- and in the last debate and again today -- that you would impose a no-fly zone to try to protect the people of Aleppo and to stop the killing there.

speaker: Wallace
text: President Obama has refused to do that because he fears it's going to draw us closer or deeper into the conflict.

speaker: Wallace
text: And General Joseph Dunford, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, says you impose a no-fly zone, chances are you're going to get into a war -- his words -- with Syria and Russia.

speaker: Wallace
text: So the question I have is, if you impose a no-fly zone -- first of all, how do you respond to their concerns?

speaker: Wallace
text: Secondly, if you impose a no-fly zone and a Russian plane violates that, does President Clinton shoot that plane down?

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, Chris, first of all, I think a no-fly zone could save lives and could hasten the end of the conflict.

speaker: Clinton
text: I'm well aware of the really legitimate concerns that you have expressed from both the president and the general.

speaker: Clinton
text: This would not be done just on the first day.

speaker: Clinton
text: This would take a lot of negotiation.

speaker: Clinton
text: And it would also take making it clear to the Russians and the Syrians that our purpose here was to provide safe zones on the ground.

speaker: Clinton
text: We've had millions of people leave Syria and those millions of people inside Syria who have been dislocated.

speaker: Clinton
text: So I think we could strike a deal and make it very clear to the Russians and the Syrians that this was something that we believe was in the best interests of the people on the ground in Syria, it would help us with our fight against ISIS.

speaker: Clinton
text: But I want to respond to what Donald said about refugees.

speaker: Clinton
text: He's made these claims repeatedly.

speaker: Clinton
text: I am not going to let anyone into this country who is not vetted, who we do not have confidence in.

speaker: Clinton
text: But I am not going to slam the door on women and children.

speaker: Clinton
text: That picture of that little 4-year-old boy in Aleppo, with the blood coming down his face while he sat in an ambulance, is haunting.

speaker: Clinton
text: And so we are going to do very careful, thorough vetting.

speaker: Clinton
text: That does not solve our internal challenges with ISIS and our need to stop radicalization, to work with American Muslim communities who are on the front lines to identify and prevent attacks.

speaker: Clinton
text: In fact, the killer of the dozens of people at the nightclub in Orlando, the Pulse nightclub, was born in Queens, the same place Donald was born.

speaker: Clinton
text: So let's be clear about what the threat is and how we are best going to be able to meet it.

speaker: Clinton
text: And, yes, some of that threat emanates from over in Syria and Iraq, and we've got to keep fighting, and I will defeat ISIS, and some of it is we have to up our game and be much smarter here at home.

speaker: Wallace
text: Folks, I want to get into our final segment.

speaker: Trump
text: But I just have to...

speaker: Trump
text: It's so ridiculous what she -- she will defeat ISIS.

speaker: Trump
text: We should have never let ISIS happen in the first place.

speaker: Trump
text: And right now, they're in 32 countries.

speaker: Trump
text: We should have -- wait one second.

speaker: Trump
text: They had a cease-fire three weeks ago.

speaker: Trump
text: A cease-fire, the United States, Russia, and Syria.

speaker: Trump
text: And during the cease-fire, Russia took over vast swatches of land, and then they said we don't want the cease-fire anymore.

speaker: Trump
text: We are so outplayed on missiles, on cease-fires.

speaker: Trump
text: They are outplayed.

speaker: Trump
text: Now, she wasn't there.

speaker: Trump
text: I assume she had nothing to do with it.

speaker: Trump
text: But our country is so outplayed by Putin and Assad, and by the way -- and by Iran.

speaker: Trump
text: Nobody can believe how stupid our leadership is.

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump, Secretary Clinton -- no, we need to move on to our final segment, and that is the national debt, which has not been discussed until tonight.

speaker: Wallace
text: Our national debt, as a share of the economy, our GDP, is now 77 percent.

speaker: Wallace
text: That's the highest since just after World War II.

speaker: Wallace
text: But the nonpartisan Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget says, Secretary Clinton, under your plan, debt would rise to 86 percent of GDP over the next 10 years.

marks.text: Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump, under your plan, they say it would rise to 105 percent of GDP over the next 10 years.

speaker: Wallace
text: The question is, why are both of you ignoring this problem?

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump, you go first.

speaker: Trump
text: Well, I say they're wrong, because I'm going to create tremendous jobs.

speaker: Trump
text: And we're bringing GDP from, really, 1 percent, which is what it is now, and if she got in, it will be less than zero.

speaker: Trump
text: But we're bringing it from 1 percent up to 4 percent.

speaker: Trump
text: And I actually think we can go higher than 4 percent.

speaker: Trump
text: I think you can go to 5 percent or 6 percent.

speaker: Trump
text: And if we do, you don't have to bother asking your question, because we have a tremendous machine.

speaker: Trump
text: We will have created a tremendous economic machine once again.

speaker: Trump
text: To do that, we're taking back jobs.

speaker: Trump
text: We're not going to let our companies be raided by other countries where we lose all our jobs, we don't make our product anymore.

speaker: Trump
text: It's very sad.

speaker: Trump
text: But I'm going to create a -- the kind of a country that we were from the standpoint of industry.

speaker: Trump
text: We used to be there.

speaker: Trump
text: We've given it up.

speaker: Trump
text: We've become very, very sloppy.

speaker: Trump
text: We've had people that are political hacks making the biggest deals in the world, bigger than companies.

speaker: Trump
text: You take these big companies, these trade deals are far bigger than these companies, and yet we don't use our great leaders, many of whom back me and many of whom back Hillary, I must say.

speaker: Trump
text: But we don't use those people.

speaker: Trump
text: Those are the people -- these are the greatest negotiators in the world.

speaker: Trump
text: We have the greatest businesspeople in the world.

speaker: Trump
text: We have to use them to negotiate our trade deals.

speaker: Trump
text: We use political hacks.

speaker: Trump
text: We use people that get the position because they gave -- they made a campaign contribution and they're dealing with China and people that are very much smarter than they are.

speaker: Trump
text: So we have to use our great people.

speaker: Trump
text: But that being said, we will create an economic machine the likes of which we haven't seen in many decades.

speaker: Trump
text: And people, Chris, will again go back to work and they'll make a lot of money.

speaker: Trump
text: And we'll have companies that will grow and expand and start from new.

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, first, when I hear Donald talk like that and know that his slogan is "Make America Great Again," I wonder when he thought America was great.

speaker: Clinton
text: And before he rushes and says, "You know, before you and President Obama were there," I think it's important to recognize that he has been criticizing our government for decades.

speaker: Clinton
text: You know, back in 1987, he took out a $100,000 ad in the New York Times, during the time when President Reagan was president, and basically said exactly what he just said now, that we were the laughingstock of the world.

speaker: Clinton
text: He was criticizing President Reagan.

speaker: Clinton
text: This is the way Donald thinks about himself, puts himself into, you know, the middle and says, "You know, I alone can fix it," as he said on the convention stage.

speaker: Clinton
text: But if you look at the debt, which is the issue you asked about, Chris, I pay for everything I'm proposing.

speaker: Clinton
text: I do not add a penny to the national debt.

speaker: Clinton
text: I take that very seriously, because I do think it's one of the issues we've got to come to grips with.

speaker: Clinton
text: So when I talk about how we're going to pay for education, how we're going to invest in infrastructure, how we're going to get the cost of prescription drugs down, and a lot of the other issues that people talk to me about all the time, I've made it very clear we are going where the money is.

speaker: Clinton
text: We are going to ask the wealthy and corporations to pay their fair share.

speaker: Clinton
text: And there is no evidence whatsoever that that will slow down or diminish our growth.

speaker: Clinton
text: In fact, I think just the opposite.

speaker: Clinton
text: We'll have what economists call middle-out growth.

speaker: Clinton
text: We've got to get back to rebuilding the middle class, the families of America.

speaker: Clinton
text: That's where growth will come from.

speaker: Clinton
text: That's why I want to invest in you.

speaker: Clinton
text: I want to invest in your family.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I think that's the smartest way to grow the economy, to make the economy fairer.

speaker: Clinton
text: And we just have a big disagreement about this.

speaker: Clinton
text: It may be because of our experiences.

speaker: Clinton
text: You know, he started off with his dad as a millionaire...

speaker: Trump
text: Yeah, yeah, we've heard -- we've heard this before, Hillary.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I think it -- you know, it's a difference that affects how we see the world and what we want to do with the economy.

speaker: Trump
text: Thank you, Hillary.

speaker: Trump
text: Could I just respond?

speaker: Wallace
text: Well, no, sir, because we're running out of time...

speaker: Trump
text: Because I did disagree with Ronald Reagan very strongly on trade.

speaker: Trump
text: I disagreed with him.

speaker: Trump
text: We should have been much tougher on trade even then.

speaker: Trump
text: I've been waiting for years.

speaker: Trump
text: And frankly, now we're going to do it right.

speaker: Wallace
text: All right.

speaker: Wallace
text: The one last area I want to get into with you in this debate is the fact that the biggest driver of our debt is entitlements, which is 60 percent of all federal spending.

speaker: Wallace
text: Now, the Committee for federal -- a Responsible Federal Budget has looked at both of your plans and they say neither of you has a serious plan that is going to solve the fact that Medicare's going to run out of money in the 2020s, Social Security is going to run out of money in the 2030s, and at that time, recipients are going to take huge cuts in their benefits.

speaker: Wallace
text: So, in effect, the final question I want to ask you in this regard is -- and let me start with you, Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump, would President Trump make a deal to save Medicare and Social Security that included both tax increases and benefit cuts, in effect, a grand bargain on entitlements?

speaker: Trump
text: I'm cutting taxes.

speaker: Trump
text: We're going to grow the economy.

speaker: Trump
text: No, it's going to totally help you.

speaker: Trump
text: And one thing we have to do: Repeal and replace the disaster known as Obamacare.

speaker: Trump
text: It's destroying our country.

speaker: Trump
text: It's destroying our businesses, our small business and our big businesses.

speaker: Trump
text: We have to repeal and replace Obamacare.

speaker: Trump
text: You take a look at the kind of numbers that that will cost us in the year '17, it is a disaster.

speaker: Trump
text: If we don't repeal and replace -- now, it's probably going to die of its own weight.

speaker: Trump
text: But Obamacare has to go.

speaker: Trump
text: It's -- the premiums are going up 60 percent, 70 percent, 80 percent.

speaker: Trump
text: Next year they're going to go up over 100 percent.

speaker: Trump
text: And I'm really glad that the premiums have started -- at least the people see what's happening, because she wants to keep Obamacare and she wants to make it even worse, and it can't get any worse.

speaker: Trump
text: Bad health care at the most expensive price.

speaker: Trump
text: We have to repeal and replace Obamacare.

speaker: Wallace
text: And, Secretary Clinton, same question, because at this point, Social Security and Medicare are going to run out, the trust funds are going to run out of money.

speaker: Wallace
text: Will you as president entertain -- will you consider a grand bargain, a deal that includes both tax increases and benefit cuts to try to save both programs?

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, Chris, I am on record as saying that we need to put more money into the Social Security Trust Fund.

speaker: Clinton
text: That's part of my commitment to raise taxes on the wealthy.

speaker: Clinton
text: My Social Security payroll contribution will go up, as will Donald's, assuming he can't figure out how to get out of it.

speaker: Clinton
text: But what we want to do is to replenish the Social Security Trust Fund...

speaker: Clinton
text: by making sure that we have sufficient resources, and that will come from either raising the cap and/or finding other ways to get more money into it.

speaker: Clinton
text: I will not cut benefits.

speaker: Clinton
text: I want to enhance benefits for low-income workers and for women who have been disadvantaged by the current Social Security system.

speaker: Clinton
text: But what Donald is proposing with these massive tax cuts will result in a $20 trillion additional national debt.

speaker: Clinton
text: That will have dire consequences for Social Security and Medicare.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I'll say something about the Affordable Care Act, which he wants to repeal.

speaker: Clinton
text: The Affordable Care Act extended the solvency of the Medicare Trust Fund.

speaker: Clinton
text: So if repeals it, our Medicare problem gets worse.

speaker: Clinton
text: What we need to do is go after...

speaker: Clinton
text: the long-term health care drivers.

speaker: Clinton
text: We've got to get costs down, increase value, emphasize wellness.

speaker: Clinton
text: I have a plan for doing that.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I think that we will be able to get entitlement spending under control by with more resources and harder decisions.

speaker: Wallace
text: This is -- this is the final time, probably to both of your delight, that you're going to be on a stage together in this campaign.

speaker: Wallace
text: I would like to end it on a positive note.

speaker: Wallace
text: You had not agreed to closing statements, but it seems to me in a funny way that might make it more interesting because you haven't prepared closing statements.

speaker: Wallace
text: So I'd like you each to take -- and we're going to put a clock up, a minute, as the final question in the final debate, to tell the American people why they should elect you to be the next president.

speaker: Wallace
text: This is another new mini-segment.

speaker: Wallace
text: Secretary Clinton, it's your turn to go first.

speaker: Clinton
text: Well, I would like to say to everyone watching tonight that I'm reaching out to all Americans -- Democrats, Republicans, and independents -- because we need everybody to help make our country what it should be, to grow the economy, to make it fairer, to make it work for everyone.

speaker: Clinton
text: We need your talents, your skills, your commitments, your energy, your ambition.

speaker: Clinton
text: You know, I've been privileged to see the presidency up close.

speaker: Clinton
text: And I know the awesome responsibility of protecting our country and the incredible opportunity of working to try to make life better for all of you.

speaker: Clinton
text: I have made the cause of children and families really my life's work.

speaker: Clinton
text: That's what my mission will be in the presidency.

speaker: Clinton
text: I will stand up for families against powerful interests, against corporations.

speaker: Clinton
text: I will do everything that I can to make sure that you have good jobs, with rising incomes, that your kids have good educations from preschool through college.

speaker: Clinton
text: I hope you will give me a chance to serve as your president.

speaker: Wallace
text: Secretary Clinton, thank you.

speaker: Wallace
text: Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump?

speaker: Trump
text: She's raising the money from the people she wants to control.

speaker: Trump
text: Doesn't work that way.

speaker: Trump
text: But when I started this campaign, I started it very strongly.

speaker: Trump
text: It's called "Make America Great Again."

speaker: Trump
text: We're going to make America great.

speaker: Trump
text: We have a depleted military.

speaker: Trump
text: It has to be helped, has to be fixed.

speaker: Trump
text: We have the greatest people on Earth in our military.

speaker: Trump
text: We don't take care of our veterans.

speaker: Trump
text: We take care of illegal immigrants, people that come into the country illegally, better than we take care of our vets.

speaker: Trump
text: That can't happen.

speaker: Trump
text: Our policemen and women are disrespected.

speaker: Trump
text: We need law and order, but we need justice, too.

speaker: Trump
text: Our inner cities are a disaster.

speaker: Trump
text: You get shot walking to the store.

speaker: Trump
text: They have no education.

speaker: Trump
text: They have no jobs.

speaker: Trump
text: I will do more for African-Americans and Latinos than she can ever do in 10 lifetimes.

speaker: Trump
text: All she's done is talk to the African-Americans and to the Latinos, but they get the vote, and then they come back, they say, we'll see you in four years.

speaker: Trump
text: We are going to make America strong again, and we are going to make America great again, and it has to start now.

speaker: Trump
text: We cannot take four more years of Barack Obama, and that's what you get when you get her.

speaker: Wallace
text: Secretary Clinton -- hold on just a moment, folks.

speaker: Wallace
text: Secretary Clinton, Mr.

speaker: Wallace
text: Trump, I want to thank you both for participating in all three of these debates.

speaker: Wallace
text: That brings to an end this year's debates sponsored by the Commission on Presidential Debates.

speaker: Wallace
text: We want to thank the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, and its students for having us.

speaker: Wallace
text: Now the decision is up to you.

speaker: Wallace
text: While millions have already voted, Election Day, November 8th, is just 20 days away.

speaker: Wallace
text: One thing everyone here can agree on: We hope you will go vote.

speaker: Wallace
text: It is one of the honors and obligations of living in this great country.
